title: Porter v. State
description: The post-conviction relief court granted Johnell Porter a new trial after finding that counsel was ineffective for failing to file a Brady motion, failing to investigate the validity of a photographic identification, and failing to interview a witness.  This Court granted the Stateâ€™s petition to review the PCR courtâ€™s decision.  We reverse.
text:
The Supreme Court of South Carolina

  
    
      
Johnell Porter, Respondent
v.
State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ORDER

Respondent (Porter) filed a petition for rehearing in which he asked the Court to reconsider its opinion reversing the post-conviction relief courtâ€™s finding of ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  
We deny the petition for rehearing, withdraw the former opinion, and substitute the attached opinion.

   
     
     
      s/Jean H. Toal                                   
        Â  C.J.
        s/James E. Moore                             
        Â Â Â Â Â  J.
        s/John H. Waller, Jr.                           
        Â Â Â Â Â  J.
        s/E. C. Burnett, III                                
        Â Â Â Â Â  J.
        s/Costa M. Pleicones                        
        Â Â Â Â Â  J.
    
  

IT IS SO ORDERED.
Columbia, South Carolina
May 1, 2006



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Johnell Porter, Respondent,
v.
State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal from Chester County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26121
Submitted October 19, 2005 - Refiled May 1, 2006Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Molly R. Crum, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Claire, South Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: The post-conviction relief (PCR) court granted Johnell Porter (Porter) a new trial after finding that counsel was ineffective for failing to file a Brady motion, failing to investigate the validity of a photographic identification, and failing to interview a witness.Â  This Court granted the Stateâ€™s petition to review the PCR courtâ€™s decision.Â  We reverse.
Factual / Procedural Background
Porter was indicted in 1980 for the armed robbery of Morris Jewelers.Â  Porter pled guilty and was sentenced to twelve years confinement, consecutive to any sentence imposed by other jurisdictions.[1]Â  Porter did not appeal his guilty plea or sentence.Â  
Porter applied for PCR in 1984.Â  The PCR petition was dismissed without prejudice, with leave to re-file when Porter returned to South Carolina to serve his sentence.Â  Porter refiled his petition for PCR in 1997, after being returned to South Carolina.Â  This petition was also dismissed.Â  Porter subsequently moved for a new PCR hearing, which was granted.Â  At the hearing, Porter argued that his trial counsel was ineffective for failing to file a Brady motion, failing to investigate the validity of a photographic identification, and failing to interview a witness.Â  The PCR judge agreed with Porter and granted Porter a new trial.Â  
The State appealed, raising the following issues for review:

  
    
      
        I.  
         Did the PCR court err in finding Porterâ€™s trial counsel ineffective for failing to file a Brady motion?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        II.   
         Did the PCR court err in finding Porterâ€™s trial counsel ineffective for failing to investigate the validity of the photographic identification?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        III.   
         Did the PCR court err in finding Porterâ€™s trial counsel ineffective for failing to interview a witness?
      
    
  

Standard of Review
This Court gives great deference to the PCR courtâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law. Â Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d 514, 517 (2000) (citing McCray v. State, 317 S.C. 557, 455 S.E.2d 686 (1995)).  On review, a PCR judgeâ€™s findings will be upheld if there is any evidence of probative value sufficient to support them.  Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 119, 386 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1989).  Â If no probative evidence exists to support the findings, this Court will reverse.  Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 144, 526 S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000) (citing Holland v. State, 322 S.C. 111, 470 S.E.2d 378 (1996)).
Law / analysis
I.                 
Brady Motion 
The State contends that the PCR court erred in finding that Porterâ€™s trial counsel was ineffective for failing to file a Brady motion.Â Â  We agree.
In order to establish a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel, a PCR applicant must prove: (1) that counsel failed to render reasonably effective assistance under prevailing professional norms; and (2) that the deficient performance prejudiced the applicant's case.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 687 (1984). Â Â An applicant may attack the voluntary and intelligent character of a guilty plea entered on the advice of counsel only by demonstrating that counselâ€™s representation was below an objective standard of reasonableness.Â Â  Roscoe v. State, 345 S.C. 16, 20, 546 S.E.2d 417, 419 (2001). Â Further, the applicant must show that there is a reasonable probability that he would have insisted on proceeding to trial on the matter instead of pleading guilty.Â  Id.Â 
Additionally, the applicant has the burden of proving the allegations of the PCR petition.Â  Bannister v. State, 333 S.C. 298, 302, 509 S.E.2d 807, 809 (1998).Â  
The Brady disclosure rule requires the prosecution to provide to the defendant any evidence in the prosecutionâ€™s possession that may be favorable to the accused and material to guilt or punishment.Â  State v. Kennerly, 331 S.C. 442, 452, 503 S.E.2d 214, 220 (Ct. App. 1998) (citing Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83, 87 (1963)).Â  Favorable evidence includes both exculpatory evidence and evidence which may be used for impeachment.Â  United States v. Bagley, 473 U.S. 667, 676, 105 S.Ct. 3375, (1985).Â  Materiality of evidence is determined based on the reasonable probability that the result of the proceeding would have been different had the evidence been disclosed to the defense.Â  Kennerly, 331 S.C. at 453, 503 S.E.2d at 220.Â  â€œA â€˜reasonable probabilityâ€™ of a different result is accordingly shown when the government's evidentiary suppression â€˜undermines confidence in the outcome of the trial.â€™â€ Bagley, 473 U.S. at 678, 105 S.Ct. at 3381.Â Â  Furthermore, the prosecution has the duty to disclose such evidence even in the absence of a request by the accused.Â  United States v. Agurs, 427 U.S. 97, 107, 96 S.Ct. 2392, (1976).Â  
In the instant case, the prosecution did not possess any material evidence which was not disclosed to Porterâ€™s trial counsel.Â  The evidence Porter claims his trial counsel failed to obtain through a Brady motion consists of the fact that the witness did not identify Porter at the crime scene.Â  This information was immaterial in light of the subsequent identification of Porter in a photographic line-up.Â  Further, Porter has failed to provide any evidence of probative value that would indicate the outcome of the proceeding would have been different.Â  Stated otherwise, the confidence of the proceeding has not been undermined.Â  Regardless of the witnessâ€™ inability to identify Porter at the scene of the crime, the fact remains that Porter was positively identified by the witness in a photographic line-up.Â Â  Moreover, Porterâ€™s co-defendant also indicated a willingness to identify Porter as one of the perpetrators.Â  In addition, Porterâ€™s trial counsel testified that he informed Porter that the solicitor would request a life sentence if Porter went to trial and was found guilty. Â Accordingly, we find that the alleged nondisclosure was not material exculpatory evidence.Â  
Â While the materiality of the evidence is important, the dispositive issue in this case is whether trial counsel rendered reasonably effective assistance under prevailing professional norms.Â  The United States Supreme Court has held that, although not required to do so by law, if a prosecutor adopts an
â€œopen file policyâ€ where the defense is allowed to review the prosecution file in satisfaction of the prosecutionâ€™s discovery obligations and the duty to disclose material exculpatory evidence as a matter of the due process clause, defense counsel may reasonably rely on that file to contain all materials the state is obligated to disclose.[2]  Â Strickler v. Greene, 527 U.S. 263, 283 n.23, 119 S.Ct. 1936, 1949 n.23 (1999).Â  
Porterâ€™s trial counsel testified at the PCR hearing that he did not file a formal Brady motion because the solicitor had an open file policy.Â  Porterâ€™s trial counsel was allowed to review all the evidence in the solicitorâ€™s file. Â Under Strickler, Porterâ€™s trial counselâ€™s failure to file the Brady motion was reasonable in light of the open file policy.Â  
 For these reasons, we find that Porterâ€™s trial counselâ€™s failure to file a Brady motion did not constitute ineffective assistance of counsel.
II.              
Photographic Line-up 
The State contends that the PCR court erred in finding that Porterâ€™s trial counsel was ineffective for failing to investigate the validity of the photographic identification.Â  We agree.
Failure to conduct an independent investigation does not constitute ineffective assistance of counsel when the allegation is supported only by mere speculation as to result.Â  Moorehead v. State, 329 S.C. 329, 334, 496 S.E.2d 415, 417 (1998).
Porterâ€™s trial counsel testified that he had the opportunity to examine the photographic line-up from which Porter was identified.Â  Counsel further testified that the line-up was reasonable.Â  The photographic line-up formed the basis upon which the arrest warrant for Porter was issued.Â  No probative evidence was presented at the PCR hearing to show that the statement in the arrest warrant was false, [3] or that the witnessâ€™s identification of Porter from the photographic line-up was false or unreasonable.Â  Additionally, no evidence was presented at the PCR hearing showing that further investigation would have lead to a different result.Â  Accordingly, we hold that Porterâ€™s trial counselâ€™s failure to further investigate the identification was not deficient, and thus did not rise to the level of ineffective assistance of counsel.
III.          
Witness Interview 
The State argues that the PCR court erred in finding that Porterâ€™s trial counsel was ineffective for failing to interview a witness.Â  We agree.
Mere speculation of what a witnessâ€™ testimony may be is insufficient to satisfy the burden of showing prejudice in a petition for PCR.Â  Bannister, 333 S.C. at 303, 509 S.E.2d at 809.
Porterâ€™s trial counsel testified that he did not interview the witness because he believed the information that was given to him by the solicitor and the chief of police was true.Â  Despite the improvidence of counselâ€™s reliance on these statements alone, Porter has not presented any evidence showing that an interview of the witness would have yielded a result different from that which Porterâ€™s trial counsel believed at the time of the plea. Â Porter pled guilty in light of the complete information that was available at that time.Â  Therefore, we hold that Porterâ€™s trial counselâ€™s failure to interview a witness did not amount to ineffective assistance of counsel.
Because we find that trial counselâ€™s performance was not deficient, Porter has not satisfied the first prong of Strickland.Â  Accordingly, a finding of prejudice is not required.
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we reverse the PCR courtâ€™s ruling and reinstate Porterâ€™s conviction and sentence. 
MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent and would affirm the post-conviction relief (PCR) judgeâ€™s order because I find there is some evidence of probative value in the record to support his findings.Â  Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 386 S.E.2d 624 (1989).
 The PCR judge found trial counsel was ineffective in failing to file a Brady motion.Â  Had such a motion been made, the State presumably would have revealed the fact that the witness who identified Porter in a photo line-up had been unable to identify him at the scene, a fact which would have had impeachment value had the witness testified at trial.
The first question is not whether the PCR court erred in finding counselâ€™s performance deficient in failing to make a Brady request, but rather there is any evidentiary support in the record for the finding.[4]Â  Cherry, supra.Â  While I may not have reached the same conclusion as the PCR judge regarding counselâ€™s performance, I cannot say it lacks evidentiary support especially in light of trial counselâ€™s testimony that he did no independent investigation but instead relied solely on information supplied by law enforcement and by the solicitorâ€™s office.
 The second question is whether the record contains any evidence of probative value to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that Porter establishedÂ  prejudice as the result of this deficient performance, that is, evidence that but for counselâ€™s deficient performance Porter would not have pled guilty but would have insisted on going to trial.Â  In my opinion, Porterâ€™s testimony that he would not have pled had he had all relevant information is sufficient to uphold the PCR judgeâ€™s prejudice finding. E.g., Solomon v. State, 313 S.C. 526, 443 S.E.2d 540 (1994) (great appellate deference to PCR judgeâ€™s credibility findings required Court to uphold judgeâ€™s determination even where testimony at PCR hearing flatly contradicted by trial record).
 While I may not have made the same findings as did the PCR judge on the failure to file a Brady motion claim, under our limited scope of review these findings should be upheld.Â  Cherry, supra.Â  I therefore respectfully dissent, and would affirm the grant of PCR to Porter.

[1] At the time of the plea, Porter was incarcerated in North Carolina.
[2] It is important to note that we do not find that the prosecution is presumed to comply with Brady simply by instituting an open file policy.Â  The duty to disclose under Brady applies to the prosecution regardless of the manner in which the prosecution chooses to do so.
[3] The Chief of Police made the sworn statement in the arrest warrant that the â€œ[d]efendant was identified as one of the suspects involved in the armed robbery of Morris Jewelers in Great Falls, SC.Â  [A witness] identified the defendant in a photo-line up [sic].â€
[4]  Certainly had the PCR found counselâ€™s performance not deficient because he reasonably relied upon the solicitorâ€™s open file policy, that finding would be upheld under Cherry.Â  Nothing in Strickler v. Greene, 527 U.S. 263 (1999), however, precludes a finding that such reliance was not reasonable.Â  This is especially so where, as here, the undisclosed evidence is not a document or other physical item, but rather something intangible, a witnessâ€™s non-identification.

title: Baxter v. Martin Brothers, Inc.
description: This is a workers' compensation case.  The Court affirmed the circuit court's order, which affirmed the order of the appellate panel of the Workers' Compensation Commission.  The Court held that a single commissioner lacks authority to award attorney fees as litigation expenses because no statute provides such authority.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Willie Baxter, Appellant,
v.
Martin Brothers, Inc, Employer, and Capital
City Insurance, Carrier, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26142
Heard March 9, 2006 - Filed May 1, 2006

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Stephen B. Samuels, of McWhirter, Bellinger & Associates, of Sumter, for Appellant.
Donald L. Van Riper, of Collins & Lacy, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  This is a workersâ€™ compensation case.Â  A single commissioner of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission awarded attorney fees to Appellant Willie Baxter (Appellant) in connection with Appellantâ€™s motion to compel Respondents Martin Brothers, Inc. and Capital City Insurance (Respondents) to comply with a consent order.Â  The commissionâ€™s appellate panel reversed the award of attorney fees, holding that under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act,[1] the commissioner lacked authority to grant such an award.Â  On further review, the circuit court affirmed the appellate panelâ€™s decision.Â  We certified the case pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and we now affirm as modified.
FACTS
After Respondents failed to satisfy most of the obligations imposed on them by the consent order, Appellant moved the commission to order Respondents to comply with the order and to hold Respondents in contempt.Â  Agreeing with Appellant that Respondents had failed to comply with the consent order, the single commissioner ordered Respondents to â€œimmediately complyâ€ with the order and to â€œprovide proof of compliance to [Appellantâ€™s] counsel within twenty days of the hearing.â€Â  The commissioner further ordered Respondents to â€œpay $250.00 to [Appellantâ€™s] counsel for attorneyâ€™s fees due as a result of bringing this Motion.â€Â  The commissioner then held that if Respondents were to fail to provide the proof of compliance within twenty days, then Respondents would â€œbe held in contemptâ€ and â€œa further hearing [would] be held to determine appropriate penalties and sanctions for contempt.â€Â  
Respondents appealed to the appellate panel, challenging only the award of attorney fees.Â  Respondents argued that the commissioner lacked authority to award attorney fees in connection with the motion, because neither the consent order nor the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act provided such authority.Â  See Blumberg v. Nealco, Inc., 310 S.C. 492, 493, 427 S.E.2d 659, 660 (1993) (citing â€œ[t]he general rule ... that attorney's fees are not recoverable unless authorized by contract or statuteâ€).Â  In response, Appellant argued that the rule that attorney fees can be awarded as a litigation expense only if permitted by statute or contract was inapplicable.Â  Appellant asserted that the commissioner had awarded attorney fees not as an expense of bringing the motion to compel, but rather as a sanction for contempt pursuant to South Carolina Code sections 42-1-540[2] and 42-3-150.[3] Â 
The appellate panel reversed the award.Â  The panel found that the single commissioner had awarded attorney fees as a litigation expense, not as a sanction for contempt.Â  The panel then held that the commissioner lacked authority to award attorney fees as a litigation expense.
Appellant appealed to the circuit court, again arguing that the commissioner had properly awarded attorney fees as a sanction for contempt.Â  The court agreed with Appellant as to the nature of the award, but nevertheless held that the decision of the appellate panel was correct.Â  The court found that under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, the commissioner lacked a general power of contempt and therefore lacked authority to award attorney fees as a sanction for contempt.Â  Thus, the court affirmed the decision of the appellate panel to reverse the award of attorney fees.
ISSUES

  
    
      
        I.  
         Whether the single commissioner awarded attorney fees as a litigation expense or as a sanction for contempt.
      
      
        
         
      
      
        II. 
        Whether the single
          commissioner had authority to award attorney fees.
      
    
  

ANALYSIS
South Carolina Code section 1-23-380(A)(6)[4] governs our review of workersâ€™ compensation decisions.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 454, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  We must determine whether the circuit court properly determined whether the appellate panelâ€™s findings of fact are supported by substantial evidence in the record and whether the panelâ€™s decision is affected by an error of law.Â  See id. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442 (holding that the full commission is â€œthe ultimate fact finderâ€). 
I.Â  Nature of the Award
It is clear from the single commissionerâ€™s order that he awarded attorney fees as an expense of bringing the motion to compel, not as a sanction for contempt.Â  The commissioner did not even hold Respondents in contempt.Â  Rather, the commissioner warned that Respondents would be held in contempt if they failed to provide proof of compliance with the consent order within twenty days of the hearing.Â  Not only did this warning not constitute a holding of contempt, but also it related to the requirement that Respondents provide proof of compliance, not to their obligation to pay attorney fees.[5]Â  
The circuit court therefore erred in reversing the appellate panelâ€™s finding that the single commissioner awarded attorney fees as a litigation expense. Â Â 
II.Â  Authority to Award Attorney Fees
As the appellate panel held, the single commissioner lacked authority to award attorney fees as a litigation expense.Â  â€œThe general rule is that attorney's fees are not recoverable unless authorized by contract or statute.â€Â  Blumberg v. Nealco, Inc., 310 S.C. 492, 493, 427 S.E.2d 659, 660 (1993).Â  Neither the consent order nor any statute provides for an award of attorney fees.Â  Although the circuit court failed to address the proper issue, the court reached the correct result in affirming the appellate panelâ€™s decision.Â  We therefore affirm as modified.
 AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, JJ., and Acting Justice Roger L. Couch, concur.

[1] S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 42-1-10 et seq. (1976 and Supp. 2005).
[2] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-540 (1976).
[3] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-3-150 (1976).
[4] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).
[5] The record indicates that Respondent failed to comply with the single commissionerâ€™s order to comply with the consent order.Â  Appellant moved the full commission to compel and to hold Respondents in contempt.Â  The full commission referred the matter to the appellate panel for resolution contemporaneous with the resolution of this attorney-fee appeal.Â  The appellate panel decided the attorney-fee issue as discussed above, but remanded the case â€œto the jurisdictional commissioner for a hearing on the [second] Motion to Compel.â€Â  Consequently, whether Respondents are in contempt for violating the single commissionerâ€™s order to comply with the consent order is not before us.

title: Layman v. State of South Carolina
description: The Court held that the State breached its statutory contract with old TERI participants.  Further, the Court remanded the breach of contract claim for old working retiree participants to the trial court.
text:
Petitioners brought this action against Respondents, the State of South Carolina and South Carolina Retirement System (Respondents or the State), alleging breach of contract


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Nancy S. Layman, David M. Fitzgerald, Vicki K.
Zelenko, Wyman M. Looney and Nancy Ahrens, on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated,
Petitioners,
v.
The State of South Carolina and The South Carolina Retirement System,
Respondents.
      
    
  


ORIGINAL JURISDICTION

Appeal from Richland County
Â John L.Â  Breeden, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26146
Heard December 1, 2005 - Filed May 4, 2006

Declaratory Judgment Issued


  
    
      
A. Camden Lewis, Keith M. Babcock, and Ariail E. King, all of Lewis Babcock & Hawkins, of Columbia; and Richard A. Harpootlian, of Columbia, for Petitioners.
Stephen Van Camp and Sarah G. Major, of Columbia; and Thornwell F. Sowell, Robert E. Stepp, Roland M. Franklin, Jr., and Tina Cundari, all of Sowell Gray Stepp Todd & Laffitte, of Columbia, for Respondents.
Andrew F. Lindemann and William H. Davidson, III, of Davidson Morrison & Lindemann, of Columbia, for Amicus Curiae State Retirees Association; Eric C. Schweitzer, of Ogletree Deakins Nash Smoak & Stewart, of Columbia, for Amicus Curiae South Carolina Chamber of Commerce; and Philip J. Mace, of Columbia, for Amicus Curiae State Employees Association. 
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: Petitioners[1] brought this action in response to the enactment on July 1, 2005 of the State Retirement System Preservation and Investment Reform Act[2] (Act 153).Â  Act 153 amends several statutes relating to the operation of the South Carolina Retirement System.Â  Specifically, Act 153 brought about significant changes for employees who participate in TERI.[3]Â  In addition, Act 153 affected employees who are not TERI participants but have retired and returned to work for the State in positions covered by the retirement system (working retiree program).[4]
In January of 2001, the South Carolina General Assembly enacted the Teacher and Employee Retention Incentive Program (TERI).Â  Hereinafter, we will refer to this statute as â€œold TERI.â€Â  In addition, we will refer to those who elected to participate in the old TERI program before July 1, 2005 as â€œold TERI participants.â€Â  Further, those eligible to retire but not participating in TERI could participate in the working retiree program.Â  We will refer to this program as the â€œold working retiree programâ€ and its participants as â€œold working retirees.â€
Pursuant to the old TERI program, old TERI participants could retire, but continue to work for the State for up to five years following their retirement.Â  During these five years, the State withheld the normal pension benefits due to old TERI participants.Â  Under the old TERI program the State paid these accrued benefits either as a lump sum at the end of five years or the old TERI participant could roll the accrued benefits over into a qualifying retirement fund.Â  Under the old TERI statute, an old TERI participant made no further employee contributions to the retirement system.Â  In return, the State was able to utilize experienced, well-trained employees for up to five years after they retired.Â  In addition, the old TERI participants did not accrue further service credit during their participation in the old TERI program and were not eligible for group life insurance or disability retirement benefits.
In contrast, under the old working retiree statute, the statute considered a working retiree to be retired and did not require the old working retiree to make further employee contributions to the system.Â  However, the old working retiree statute limited the old working retiree to making no more than $50,000 per year in salary.
Petitioners (old TERI program participants and old working retiree participants) who retired before July 1, 2005 under the old TERI program or pursuant to the old working retiree statute brought this action against the State of South Carolina and South Carolina Retirement System (Respondents or the State), alleging breach of contract.Â  In addition, the old TERI program participants and old working retiree participants argue the State should be estopped from retroactively applying new legislation to Petitioners.Â  Finally, the old TERI program participants and old working retiree participants claim violations of the Takings and Due Process Clauses of the State and Federal Constitutions.Â  This Court granted Petitionersâ€™ request for the case to be heard in the Courtâ€™s original jurisdiction.Â  We hold that the State unlawfully breached its contract with those Petitioners participating in the old TERI program.Â  In addition, we remand the old working retiree participantsâ€™ breach of contract claim to the trial court for action consistent with this opinion.
Factual / Procedural Background
The portion of Act 153 at the center of this controversy pertains to a financial contribution that old TERI and old working retiree participants are now required to submit to the retirement system.Â  The changes wrought by Act 153 dramatically alter the former versions of the TERI and working retiree statutes.Â  Under the prior enactment of the TERI and working retiree programs, neither the old TERI participants nor the old working retiree participants were required to contribute to the retirement system.Â  Under the terms of the prior programs, for all intents and purposes, both the old TERI participants and the old working retiree participants were considered to be retired.Â  
Petitioners claim that the requirement that they now contribute 6.25% of their annual salary to the retirement program constitutes a breach of contract.[5]Â  In the alternative, if no contract is found, Petitioners assert that the State should be estopped from requiring further contributions due to Petitionersâ€™ reliance on the terms of the former TERI and working retiree programs.Â  Further, Petitioners claim that the enactment of Act 153 constitutes an unconstitutional taking and a deprivation of their property without due process of law.
Previously, Petitioners sought a temporary restraining order seeking to enjoin the State from collecting Petitionersâ€™ contributions to the retirement system.Â  The circuit court granted the motion, preventing the State from collecting contributions from the four named Petitioners in this case.Â  Respondents appealed and petitioned for a writ of supersedeas.Â  However, while the motions were pending in the circuit court, the case was certified to the Supreme Court pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  As a result, Petitioners filed a petition for original jurisdiction. 
This Court denied the Stateâ€™s petition for supersedeas, but granted the petition for original jurisdiction.Â  In addition, Petitioners filed a motion for class certification, which the Court granted.Â  The class was deemed to consist of all participants who had retired under the old TERI program under the former version of Â§ 9-1-2210, and all those participants considered old working retirees under the previous version of Â§ 9-1-1790; all of whom elected to participate in the programs before July 1, 2005.Â  Further, the Court ordered all contributions withdrawn from the class members be transferred into an interest bearing account and escrowed pending the outcome of this litigation.Â Â  As a result, the following issues are before the Court:

  
    
      
        I.   
         Do the statutory provisions of the former versions of the TERI and the working retiree programs create contracts?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        II.   
         Is the State estopped from requiring Petitioners to make contributions to the retirement system?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        III.  
         Does the enactment of Act 153 constitute an unconstitutional taking under either the State or Federal Constitution?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        IV. 
         Does Act 153 violate the Due Process Clause of the State or Federal Constitution?
      
    
  

Law / Analysis
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Breach of Contract
A.Â Â Â Â Â  TERI Program
Old TERI program participants argue that the statutory provisions governing old TERI participants created contracts which the State breached by requiring previously enrolled TERI participants to contribute to the retirement system.Â  We agree.
Generally, statutes do not create contractual rights.Â  Natâ€™l R.R. Passenger Corp. v. Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Ry. Co., 470 U.S. 451, 465-66 (1985).Â Â Â  However, if the statute indicates that the legislature intended to bind itself contractually, a contract may be found to exist.Â  Id.Â  In South Carolina, contractual rights are created by statute only when they are expressly found in the language of the legislation.Â  See S.C. Public Serv. Auth. v. Summers, 282 S.C. 148, 318 S.E.2d 113 (1984).
With the above guidelines in mind, we turn to the prior version of the TERI statute, enacted in 2001, to determine if a contract existed.Â  In the present case, the relevant portions of the prior statute provide that a member of the State Retirement Systerm eligible to retire may:

[e]lect to participate in the Teacher and Employee Retention Incentive Program (program). A member electing to participate in the program retires for purposes of the system, and the memberâ€™s normal retirement benefit is calculated on the basis of the memberâ€™s average final compensation and service credit at the time the program period begins. The program participant shall agree to continue employment with an employer participating in the system for a program period, not to exceed five years.
. . . . 

(B) During the specified program period, receipt of the memberâ€™s normal retirement benefit is deferred. The memberâ€™s deferred monthly benefit must be placed in the system's trust fund on behalf of the member. No interest is paid on the memberâ€™s deferred monthly benefit placed in the systemâ€™s trust fund during the specified program period.
. . . . 
(D) A program participant is retired from the retirement system as of the
beginning of the program period. A program participant makes no further employee contributions to the system, accrues no service credit during the program period, and is not eligible to receive group life insurance benefits or disability retirement benefits. Accrued annual leave and sick leave used in any manner in the calculation of the program participantâ€™s retirement benefit is deducted from the amount of such leave accrued by the participant.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-1-2210 (Supp. 2004) (emphasis added).Â  
In sum, the above former statutory authority (old TERI) provided a means for eligible employees to retire, but continue to work subject to several limitations.Â  Under the old TERI program, an employee could retire, but continue to work for an additional five years after retirement.Â  Instead of receiving their retirement check, the old TERI program participantsâ€™ retirement money was placed in a non-interest bearing account to be paid out at the end of the five-year program period.Â  During the five year period, under the prior statute, the employees were deemed retired and made no further contributions to the retirement system out of their paycheck.Â  In addition, old TERI program participants gave up the opportunity to accrue further service credit, thus, any increase in salary would not result in an increase in retirement benefits.Â  In return, the State was able to retain a large number of experienced and well-trained employees for a period not to exceed five years.
As a result of the enactment of Act 153, old TERI participants are now required â€œto pay to the system the employee contribution as if a program participant were an active contributing member,â€ while gaining no additional service credit.Â  Act No. 153, 2005 S.C. Acts 1697.
We hold that the language in the old TERI statute demonstrates, in unambiguous terms, the intent of the legislature to bind itself to the terms in the statute.Â  We find it telling that the legislature used terms that are indicative of a contract: â€œA . . . member who is eligible [to retire under TERI]. . . and complies with the requirements of this article . . . . shall agree . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-1-2210 (A) (emphasis added).Â  Far from simply describing the terms of old TERI participantsâ€™ employment, the former TERI statute outlined an employment program in which those employees eligible for retirement could enroll for a fixed period of time up to five years.[6]Â  The old TERI statute fixed obligations, required affirmative actions by both the State and old TERI program participants, and contained contractually significant language. 
We next consider whether there was a breach of the agreement.Â  When the State, through Act 153, sought to collect retirement contributions from the old TERI participants, it was in clear breach of the contract it created by the relevant statutes.Â  Once the bargain is formed, and the obligations set, a contract may only be altered by mutual agreement and for further consideration.Â  We find that, as applied to old TERI participants, the enactment of Act 153 constitutes a breach of contract.Â  Therefore, we hold the State may not unilaterally alter its agreement with old TERI program participants by forcing the old TERI participants to contribute to the retirement system.[7]Â  
The State argues that the statutes did not create a binding contract and that this case is â€œon all foursâ€ with Alston v. City of Camden.Â  322 S.C. 38, 46, 471 S.E.2d 174, 178 (1996).Â  In Alston, this Court held that employees generally have no contractual rights in their employment merely by virtue of a city ordinance describing the terms of their employment.Â  Id. at 45, 471 S.E.2d at 177.Â  We find that Alston is distinguishable in several respects.Â  First, the Court held that the benefits affected in Alston were â€œfringe benefits,â€ and that the employee had a reasonable expectation that those benefits might be subject to change.Â  Id. at 48, 471 S.E.2d 179.Â  In addition, the agreement in Alston was the type of unilateral contract that is subject to modification at any time.Â  Id. at 48-49, 471 S.E.2d at 179.
Our holding in the present case rests not on general principles of contract law, but rather, on the plain meaning of the language used by the legislature in the old TERI statute.Â  Unlike the city ordinance in Alston, Act 153 sought to materially alter terms which formed a substantial part of the basis for the bargain struck between the State and old TERI participants.Â  In these limited circumstances, we read the old TERI statute to go beyond terms of employment to create a defined employment program.Â  While our rule has been, and continues to be, that statutes do not create contracts that bind the State, the State may not utilize such significant contractual language and disregard its plain meaning and practical effect.
Further, our holding today does not hamper the legislatureâ€™s ability to govern.Â  The new TERI program will continue in its current form and all participants in the new TERI program, enacted via Act 153, will be subject to the terms of that statute.Â  Further, and contrary to the Stateâ€™s suggestion, our holding will not place the actuarial soundness of the retirement system in ruins.Â  The Stateâ€™s contention that the unfunded accounting liability amortization period will be close to reaching its thirty year limits is based on an assumption that 100 percent of eligible retirees will participate in the old TERI program.Â  This is inaccurate in two respects.Â  First, old TERI participants do not contend that the program cannot be changed with respect to future participants enrolled after July 1, 2005.Â  As a result, the study fails to recognize that under the new TERI program, new TERI participants enrolled after July 1, 2005 will contribute to the retirement system as set forth in Act No. 153.Â  In fact, the study relied upon by the State is based upon an incorrect assumption.Â  This inaccuracy is outlined in the record before this Court in an affidavit relied upon heavily by the State in the claim that the retirement system will reach near crisis.Â  The affidavit of a consulting actuary from Milliman, Inc. stated: â€œif current and future TERI retirees and reemployed retirees do not pay the member contribution . . . .â€ (emphasis added).Â  The opinion of this Court does not affect the decision of the State to require new or future TERI participants, those enrolled after July 1, 2005, to make retirement contributions.Â  
Second, the contention that the number of old TERI participants is growing at a rapid pace is a complete misrepresentation.Â  The numbers of participants in the old TERI program is diminishing with each passing day and by June 30, 2010, the number of old TERI program participants will be zero.Â  Any new TERI participants (those enrolled after July 1, 2005) are covered by Act 153 and will make contributions to the system as directed by the new requirements of Act 153. 
Based on the above, we find that the provision of the old TERI statute created a binding contract and hold that the State breached that contract by applying the requirements of Act 153 to old TERI participants enrolled prior to July 1, 2005.[8]
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Working Retirees
Petitioners argue that the statutory provisions governing old working retirees created contracts which the State breached by requiring previously enrolled working retirees to contribute to the retirement system.Â  We disagree.
A person eligible for retirement could have elected to become a working retiree.Â  A working retiree is outlined under the former statute as:

[A] retired member of the system who has been retired for at least sixty days may return to employment covered by the system and earn up to fifty thousand dollars a fiscal year without affecting the monthly retirement allowance he is receiving from the system.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-1-1790 (A) (Supp. 2004).Â  As an old working retiree, a person would be paid their retirement check.Â  Instead of having the retirement check placed in an escrow account like the old TERI program, the old working retiree received the monthly check and could invest the money as he or she saw fit.Â  An old working retiree was also considered to be retired, and as a result, did not make further contributions to the retirement system.Â  However, in order to retain both his retirement check and normal pay, an old working retiree was limited to earning $50,000 in salary.
As outlined above in this opinion, absent clear statutory language indicating an intent by the legislature to bind itself contractually, a statute does not create a contract.Â  Natâ€™l R.R. Passenger Corp. v. Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Ry. Co., 470 U.S. 451, 465-66 (1985).
In the present case, the old working retiree statute does not use the same contractually significant language as utilized in the old TERI statute.Â  As a result, we hold that the old working retiree statute does not create a binding contract between the State and the old working retirees prohibiting the State from altering the statute exempting old working retirees from further contributions to the retirement system.Â  Stated differently, the old working retiree statute does not evidence an intent by the legislature to be bound to any terms related to the old working retiree program.
However, the record contains evidence indicating that some of the old working retirees may have written contracts detailing the terms of the old working retiree program, including the promise that the old working retirees would not have to make further contributions to the retirement system.Â  These documents, if signed by both parties upon enrollment in the old working retiree program, might reflect what agreement, if any, was made.Â  In addition, some of the old working retirees who do not have signed documents may have relied upon statements made by the State in making a decision to retire and become a working retiree under the prior statute.
As a result, we remand the issue of breach of contract as to the old working retirees to the trial court for a case by case factual determination of whether any actions of the State with regard to individual old working retirees constituted a breach of contract.
Issues II, III, and IV
Because we find that the old TERI statute created a binding contract, we do not address the remaining issues.
Conclusion
Based on the above reasoning, we hold that the State breached its contract with Petitioners who were enrolled as old TERI participants by forcing those old TERI participants to make retirement system contributions.Â  Accordingly, all retirement system contributions withheld from old TERI participants enrolled prior to July 1, 2005 shall be returned with interest to such TERI participants and no further contributions from TERI participants enrolled prior to July 1, 2005 shall be required.Â  
It should be noted that our decision today is a very narrow one which affects only those TERI participants who joined the old TERI program, originally enacted in 2001, prior to July 1, 2005.Â  This Court has previously ordered that all disputed contributions be escrowed in an interest bearing account during this litigation and as a result this money is available to be returned to the TERI participants.Â  Both the State and the old TERI participants were protected by this Court in its order requiring the disputed funds be escrowed in an interest bearing account.Â  Thus, under this Courtâ€™s previous order, the disputed retirement system contributions have been segregated in a separate account during the course of this litigation, and now the State has the funds readily available to accomplish the refund ordered herein.
The new TERI program as adopted by the legislature in Act 153 continues to be valid and all those participants joining after July 1, 2005 are subject to the entirety of the requirements outlining the new TERI program in Act 153.Â  It is fully within the power of the legislature to make changes to laws that impact future participants, but as outlined in this opinion, the State breached its contract with the old TERI participants by changing the terms of the existing statutory agreement after participants agreed to those terms by electing to retire.Â  
Finally, we remand the issue of breach of contract as related to the old working retirees to the trial court.Â  The record before this Court does not allow us to make the factual or legal inquiry necessary to determine if a binding contract existed between the State and the old working retirees regarding the making of further retirement system contributions. Â 
MOORE, BURNETT, JJ., and Acting Justices Perry M. Buckner and D. L. Jefferson, concur.

[1] Petitioners consist of a class defined as:

All persons currently employed by an employer participating in the South Carolina Retirement System who elected prior to July 1, 2005, the effective date of Act 153, to participate in the Teacher and Employee Retention Incentive Program (TERI) pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-1-2210, et seq, as well as all retired members of the System who have returned to employment covered by the System prior to July 1, 2005, and are not currently TERI participants.

[2] Act No. 153, 2005 S.C. Acts 1697.
[3] The TERI program is codified at S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-1-2210 (Supp. 2004).
[4] Terms of employment for Retiree participants are codified at S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-1-1790 (Supp. 2004).
[5] The contribution will increase to 6.5% in 2006.
[6] Most of the TERI participants are continuing contract teachers and each year the employment contracts of the participants in TERI are subject to renewal, unless the teacher is fired for cause.Â  But the TERI program was available for those employees eligible to participate for up to five years.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-26-40 (Supp. 2004) (explaining the various contract levels for teachers).
[7] The State should have treated the retirement contributions by old TERI participants in the same manner in which the State treated the old TERI participants with regard to the grievance system.Â  In Act 153, Section 3, the State exempted old TERI participants from the change in Act 153 related to the grievance procedure for employees.Â  The State should have exempted old TERI participants from all portions of Act 153 related to the new TERI program, instead of applying new legislation to old TERI participants.
[8] This holding has almost the same effect on the old TERI participants as envisioned under H. 4544, introduced to the House of Representatives in January of 2006.Â  See S.C. H. 4544, 116th Gen. Assembly, 2nd Reg. Sess. (Jan. 31, 2006)Â  (stating that persons who began participation in the Teacher and Employee Retention Incentive Program (TERI) before July 1, 2005, or who were reemployed retirees who returned to employment of employers covered under the South Carolina Retirement System (SCRS) or the South Carolina Police Officers Retirement System (SCPORS) before July 1, 2005, are exempt from the payment of employee contributions otherwise due SCRS or SCPORS with respect to employment after June 30, 2005.Â  The exemption continues for these employees through the termination of TERI participation and while a reemployed retiree remains employed in the position held before July 1, 2005.Â  SCRS and SCPORS shall refund without interest the employee contributions made by the TERI program participants and reemployed retirees receiving the exemption allowed pursuant to this joint resolution).Â  However, this Court ordered the withheld contributions be placed in an interest bearing account during this litigation.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of Spartanburg County Magistrate Johnny Lee Cash, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26143
Submitted April 18, 2006 - Filed May 8, 2006

REMOVED FROM OFFICE


  
    
      
        Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Robert E. Bogan, Assistant Deputy Attorney General, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
        Robert M. Holland, of Spartanburg, for respondent.Â Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  In this judicial disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21, RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of any sanction set forth in Rule 7(b), RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  The facts as set forth in the Agreement are as follows.Â  
FACTS

On November 2, 1991, respondent was married.Â  He worked as a magistrateâ€™s constable for several years, became a part-time magistrate in the late 1990s and, eventually, a full-time magistrate in 2001.Â  
Respondent met Female 1 when he was working as a magistrateâ€™s constable.Â  They were co-workers on friendly terms until sometime in the summer of 2003 when she began to confide in respondent about certain employment-related concerns and her fear that her job was in jeopardy due to circumstances involving another magistrate.Â  
Female 1 became aware that respondent frequently worked on a boat at a friendâ€™s house during the evening.Â  Respondent told Female 1 they could talk at the friendâ€™s house.
Female 1 met respondent at the friendâ€™sâ€™ house on a few occasions and, on at least one of those occasions, engaged in sexual activity.Â  The sexual activity constituted adultery.Â  
Respondent and Female 1 acknowledge engaging in sexual activity on a second occasion. 
Female 1 reported to ODC that, although she did have a close relationship with respondent, she viewed respondentâ€™s flirting as horseplay and never took it seriously.Â  Female 1 later informed ODC that she engaged in sexual activity with respondent only because his first initiation of sex surprised her and, due to her fragile emotional state caused by other employment-related concerns, including fear of losing her job, she believed she could not refuse his advances.Â  
Respondent represents he believed the sexual activity with Female 1 was mutually desired.Â  Respondent also represents that Female 1 neither appeared emotionally fragile nor did she say or do anything to suggest to him that her involvement was other than completely free and voluntary.Â Â  Â Â Â Â 
Female 2 has worked for the Magistrate Court for more than twenty years.Â  Respondent met her while he was a constable.Â  When he became Chief Magistrate in early 2004, respondentâ€™s supervisory responsibilities caused him to interact more frequently with Female 2.Â  
According to respondent, he and Female 2 realized they were both in failed relationships with their spouses and eventually fell in love.Â  Respondent acknowledges engaging in extra-marital sexual activity with Female 2 on several occasions while she was employed by the Spartanburg Magistrate Court, including on two occasions while attending court-related seminars out of town. 
On March 18, 2005, respondentâ€™s wife filed a complaint seeking a divorce from respondent on the ground of adultery.Â  The divorce was granted by order filed August 5, 2005.Â  Female 2 was also divorced from her husband and, subsequently, married respondent.Â  Both continue to be employed in the Spartanburg Central Magistrate Court.
Before respondentâ€™s romantic relationship with Female 2, but while he was the Chief Magistrate, respondent made administrative changes in the Spartanburg Central Magistrate Court that included a promotion for Female 2.Â  Respondent contends the promotion was based exclusively on merit, experience, and longevity, but acknowledged that, in hindsight, it may have had the appearance of being based on favoritism.Â  
LAW

By his misconduct, respondent admits he has violated the following Canons of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR:Â  Canon 1 (judge shall uphold integrity of the judiciary); Canon 1A (judge should participate in establishing, maintaining, and enforcing high standards of conduct and shall personally observe those standards so that the integrity and independence of the judiciary will be preserved); Canon 2 (judge shall avoid impropriety and the appearance of impropriety in all activities); Canon 2A (judge shall respect and comply with the law and shall act at all times in a manner that promotes public confidence in the integrity and impartiality of the judiciary); Canon 4 (judge shall conduct his extra-judicial activities as to minimize the risk of conflict with his judicial obligations); and Canon 4A(2) (judge shall conduct all extra-judicial activities so they do not demean the judicial office).Â  By violating the Code of Judicial Conduct, respondent admits he has also violated Rule 7(a)(1) of the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  
CONCLUSION 

We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and remove respondent from office.Â  It is therefore ordered that respondent be removed from office as of the date of the filing of this opinion. Â Â Â Â 
REMOVED FROM OFFICE.Â  
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of Dillon County Magistrate John R. Davis, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26144
Submitted April 18, 2006 - Filed May 8, 2006

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


  
    
      
        Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Deborah S. McKeown, Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, of Columbia, for The Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
        John R. Davis, of Latta, pro se.Â Â Â  
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this judicial disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of a public reprimand pursuant to Rule 7(b), RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  We accept the agreement and impose a public reprimand.Â  The facts as set forth in the agreement are as follows.Â  
FACTS

At approximately 11:30 p.m. on October 1, 2005, Officer Jones of the Latta Police Department arrested an individual, respondentâ€™s uncle, for driving under the influence and, thereafter, transported him to the Dillon County Detention Center.Â  At approximately 12:35 a.m. on the morning of October 2, 2005, respondentâ€™s uncle registered a 0.14% on the Datamaster test administered at the detention center by Trooper Byrd.Â  
Thereafter, respondentâ€™s uncle contacted respondent from the detention center and advised he had been arrested for driving under the influence.Â  At approximately 1:20 a.m., respondent entered the booking area at the Dillon County Detention Center, conducted a special bond proceeding for his uncle, and allowed his uncle to sign a personal recognizance bond.Â  Respondent then left the detention center; he did not ascertain whether there were other inmates awaiting bond hearings.Â  At approximately 1:41 a.m., respondent was released by the detention center.Â Â  
Respondent acknowledges he should not have presided over his uncleâ€™s bond hearing.Â  He further acknowledges he was not the magistrate on call that evening, that he did not seek permission to conduct the special bond proceeding, that he failed to ascertain if there were other inmates awaiting bond hearings, and that he did not conduct bond hearings for any other hearings awaiting bond hearings.Â  Respondent also failed to inform the chief magistrate that a special bond proceeding had been conducted.Â Â  Â 
On one prior occasion in 2004, respondent conducted a special bond hearing for a defendant charged with two counts of burglary and grand larceny and released that defendant on a personal recognizance bond.Â  In that matter, respondent failed to notify the victim of the bond hearing, failed to ascertain if there were other inmates awaiting bond hearings, and did not conduct bond hearings for any other inmates awaiting bond hearings.Â  Respondent also failed to inform the chief magistrate that a special bond proceeding had been conducted.Â  Â Â Â  
Respondent acknowledges that the preferential treatment given by him to these two defendants violated the Chief Justiceâ€™s Administrative Order of November 29, 2000, as well as the Code of Judicial Conduct.Â  ODC states that, to its best knowledge and belief, respondent has been forthright and fully cooperative with its inquires into this matter.Â  
LAW

By his misconduct, respondent has violated the following Canons of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR:Â  Canon 1 (judge shall uphold integrity of the judiciary); Canon 1A (judge should participate in establishing, maintaining, and enforcing high standards of conduct, and shall personally observe those standards so that the integrity of the judiciary will be preserved); Canon 2 (judge shall avoid impropriety in all activities); Canon 2A (judge shall respect and comply with the law and shall act at all times in a manner that promotes public confidence in the integrity of the judiciary); Canon 2B (judge shall not allow familial or other relationships to influence his judicial conduct or judgment); Canon 3 (judge shall perform duties of judicial office impartially and diligently); Canon 3(B)(1) (judge shall hear and decide matters assigned to the judge except in those in which disqualification is required);Â  Canon 3B(2) (judge shall be faithful to the law and maintain professional competence in it); Canon 3B(5) (judge shall perform judicial duties without bias or prejudice); Canon 3(B)(7)Â  (judge shall not consider ex parte communications); Canon 3B(8) (judge shall dispose of all judicial matters promptly, efficiently, and fairly); Canon 3(E)(1)(a) (judge shall disqualify himself where he has a personal bias or prejudice concerning a party); and Canon 3(E)(1)(d)(i) (judge shall disqualify himself where a person within the third degree of relationship is a party to the proceeding).Â  Respondent further admits he has also violatedÂ  the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to violate the Code of Judicial Conduct), Rule 7(a)(7) (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to willfully violate a valid court order issued by a court of this state), and Rule 7(a)(9) (it shall be a ground for discipline for judge to violated the Judgeâ€™s Oath of Office). Â 
CONCLUSION 

We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and issue a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, respondent is hereby reprimanded for his misconduct.Â  
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.
