text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Edward D. Sloan, individually and as a citizen and taxpayer and registered elector of the State of South Carolina, and on behalf of all others similarly situated, Appellant,
v.
Friends of the Hunley, Inc., and Warren F.
Lasch, its Chairman, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Richland County
John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26151
Heard November 2, 2005 - Filed May 15, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Jennifer J. Miller, and James G. Carpenter, both of Carpenter Law Firm, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Thornwell F. Sowell, III, of Sowell Gray Stepp & Laffitte, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  


 CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This case was certified for review from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  Appellant Edward D. Sloan Jr. (Sloan) brought an action against Friends of the Hunley, Inc. (Friends) and its chairman, Warren F. Lasch (Lasch), seeking injunctive and declaratory relief for a violation of the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA).Â  After the commencement of the litigation, Friends provided Sloan with the requested information.Â  Friends subsequently moved for summary judgment, arguing that the action was moot and that Sloan lacked standing.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment in favor of Friends on all causes of action.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
Factual / Procedural Background
Friends is a nonprofit corporation dedicated to the recovery and conservation of the Confederate submarine, the H.L. Hunley. Sloan requested documents from Friends pursuant to FOIA in July of 2001.Â  Friends refused to provide the requested documents contending that the corporation was not subject to FOIA.Â  Sloan filed a Complaint alleging that Friends has received more than $13,000,000 in public funds, is a public body as defined by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-20(a) (1991), and has violated FOIA by refusing to provide certain documents to Sloan after a FOIA request.Â  Sloan also alleged that Friends is merely the alter ego of the Hunley Commission (the Commission) and is, therefore, subject to all laws applicable to the Commission including
FOIA.  
Friends sought summary judgment arguing that Sloanâ€™s cause of action for a declaratory judgment finding Friends a public body subject to FOIA was moot because they had fully complied with Sloanâ€™s FOIA request.Â  The trial court granted Friendsâ€™ motion for summary judgment.Â  Friends subsequently filed a motion for summary judgment with a second trial court contending that Sloanâ€™s alter ego cause of action improperly called on the Court to render an advisory opinion and also that Sloan did not have standing to maintain an action to establish Friends as the alter ego of the Commission.Â  Judge John C. Hayes, III granted Friendsâ€™ motion, finding that the action essentially required an advisory opinion and that Sloan lacked sufficient standing.Â  Sloan appealed and raises the following issues for review:

  
    
      
        I.    
         Did the trial court err in declining to consider whether Friends was a â€œpublic bodyâ€ under
          FOIA?
      
      
        
        
      
      
        II. 
         Did the trial court err in finding that Sloan lacks standing?
      
      
        
        
      
      
        III.
         Did the trial court err in granting Friendsâ€™ motion for summary judgment as to the alter ego claim?
      
    
  

Lasch raises the following issue for review as an additional sustaining ground:

  
    
      
        IV.  
         Is Lasch entitled to summary judgment because he is being sued only in his capacity as the chairman of Friends?
      
    
  

Law / Analysis
Standard of Review
In reviewing the grant of summary judgment, this Court applies the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56, SCRCP:Â  summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  South Carolina Elec. & Gas Co. v. Town of Awenda, 359 S.C. 29, 34, 596 S.E.2d 482, 485 (2004) (quoting Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001)).Â  On appeal, all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence must be viewed in a light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id.
I.                 
Declaratory Judgment 
A.Â  Mootness
Sloan argues that the trial court erred in declining to consider whether Friends was a â€œpublic bodyâ€ under FOIA. [1]Â  We disagree.
Generally, this Court only considers cases presenting a justiciable controversy.Â  Byrd v. Irmo High School, 321 S.C. 426, 430, 468 S.E.2d 861, 864 (1996).Â  A justiciable controversy exists when there is a real and substantial controversy which is appropriate for judicial determination, as distinguished from a dispute that is contingent, hypothetical, or abstract.Â  Id at 431, 468 S.E.2d at 864.Â  A moot case exists where a judgment rendered by the court will have no practical legal effect upon an existing controversy because an intervening event renders any grant of effectual relief impossible for the reviewing court.Â  Mathis v. South Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t, 260 S.C. 344, 346, 195 S.E.2d 713, 715 (1973).Â  Â If there is no actual controversy, this Court will not decide moot or academic questions.Â  Id. (citing Â Jones v. Dillon-Marion Human Res. Dev. Commâ€™n., 277 S.C. 533, 535, 291 S.E.2d 195, 196 (1982)); see also Wallace v. City of York, 276 S.C. 693, 694, 281 S.E.2d 487, 488 (1981).Â Â  Although this Court has not addressed the issue of mootness as it pertains to FOIA, other courts have held that once the requested documents are produced, a justiciable controversy no longer exists.Â  Trueblood v. U.S. Dept. of Treasury, I.R.S., 943 F.Supp. 64, 67 (D.D.C. 1996); Misegades & Douglas v. Schuyler, 456 F.2d 255, 255 (4th Cir. 
1972); Kaye v. Burns, 411 F.Supp. 897, 901 (S.D.N.Y. 1976).Â Â Â  
In the instant case, Sloan concedes that Friends has provided all documents requested pursuant to FOIA.Â  Additionally, since the filing of this appeal, Friends has conceded that it is presently a public body as related to this litigation.Â  The purpose of FOIA is to protect the public by providing a mechanism for the disclosure of information by public bodies.Â  Bellamy v. Brown, 305 S.C 291, 295, 408 S.E.2d 219, 221 (1991).Â  Because the information Sloan sought has been disclosed, there is no continuing violation of FOIA upon which the trial court could have issued a declaratory judgment.Â  Additionally, Sloan has further conceded that his interest in this matter is purely academic.Â  Therefore, we find that the question is moot, and any judgment by this Court would constitute an advisory opinion.Â Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not err in granting Friendsâ€™ motion for summary judgment as to Sloanâ€™s request for a declaratory judgment.
B.Â  Exceptions to Mootness
Sloan further contends that the trial court erred in finding that none of the general exceptions to mootness applied in this case.Â  We disagree.Â  
Two exceptions in which the court may address an issue despite mootness are 1) when the issue raised is capable of repetition, yet evading review, and 2) when the question considers matters of important public interest.Â  Curtis v. State of South Carolina, 345 S.C. 557, 568, 549 S.E.2d 591, 596 (2001).Â Â  Neither exception applies in this case.
In evaluating whether a moot issue is capable of repetition, yet evading review the Court does not require that the complaining party be subject to the action again.Â  Byrd, 321 S.C. at 431, 468 S.E.2d at 864.Â  However, the action must be one which will truly evade review.Â  Id at 432, 468 S.E.2d at 864 (finding short term student suspensions will evade review because they are, â€œby their very nature, completed long before an appellate court can review the issues they implicateâ€); but see Seabrook v. City of Folly Beach, 337 S.C. 304, 307, 523 S.E.2d 462, 463 (1999) (holding that an action that is capable of repetition does not necessarily evade review).Â  
In Seabrook, the plaintiffs brought an action against the city alleging that the city imposed conditions on a residential development for which it had no authority.Â  337 S.C. at 304, 523 S.E.2d at 462.Â  After the trial court found in favor of the plaintiffs, the city removed the conditions and approved the plat.Â  In reviewing the appeal this Court found that the issue was moot, and that although the scenario was capable of repetition, it did not evade review.Â  
The instant case is analogous to Seabrook.Â  Although Friends admits that the current situation is capable of repetition, it does not evade review.Â  Should another person bring an action against Friends for a violation of FOIA and Friends fails to produce the requested documents, the Court will have the opportunity to review the issue.
In determining whether a moot issue should be reviewed under the public importance exception, the issue must present a question of imperative and manifest urgency requiring the establishment of a rule for future guidance in â€œmatters of important public interest.â€Â  Sloan v. Greenville County, 361 S.C. 568, 570, 606 S.E.2d 464, 465-66 (2004) (citing Curtis, 345 S.C. at 568, 549 S.E.2d at 596).Â  This evaluation must be made based on the facts of each individual situation.Â  Id at 571, 606 S.E.2d at 466.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Sloanâ€™s contention that his declaratory judgment action meets the public importance exception despite mootness is unsupported.Â  Â Sloan does not present a â€œquestion of imperative and manifest urgency.â€Â  Because Friends produced the requested documents, Sloan has been afforded the intended benefit of FOIA.Â  Even assuming that this issue presents a matter of public importance, no imperative or manifest urgency exists in light of Friendsâ€™ producing the requested documents and conceding that it is presently a public body under FOIA.
Accordingly, we hold that neither exception applies in this case.Â  Therefore, we affirm the ruling of the trial court. 
II.              
Standing 
Sloan contends that the trial court erred in ruling that he did not have standing to bring this action.Â Â  We agree.
Generally, a party must be a real party in interest to the litigation to have standing.Â  Evins v. Richland County Historic Pres. Commâ€™n, 341 S.C. 15, 21, 532 S.E.2d 876, 879 (2000) (citing Glaze v. Grooms, 324 S.C. 249, 478 S.E.2d 841 (1996)). Â A real party in interest is a party with a real, material, or substantial interest in the outcome of the litigation.Â  Baird v. Charleston County, 333 S.C. 519, 530, 511 S.E.2d 69, 75 (1999).Â  Â However, the South Carolina General Assembly addressed the issue of standing in FOIA cases in a specific statutory provision.Â  The statute provides: 

[a]ny citizen of the State may apply to the circuit court for either or both a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief to enforce the provisions of this chapter in appropriate cases as long as such application is made no later than one year following the date on which the alleged violation occurs or one year after a public vote in public session, whichever comes later. The court may order equitable relief as it considers appropriate, and a violation of this chapter must be considered to be an irreparable injury for which no adequate remedy at law exists.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-100(a) (1991).Â  Additionally, this Court has held that standing under FOIA does not require the information seeker to have a â€œpersonal stake in the outcome.â€Â  Fowler v. Beasley, 322 S.C. 463, 466, 472 S.E.2d 630, 632 (1996).
Accordingly, we find that the trial court erred in finding that Sloan lacked standing to bring this action. 
III.          
Alter Ego Theory 
Sloan argues that the trial court erred in granting Friendsâ€™ motion for summary judgment as to the alter ego claim. We find no necessity to address this issue.
The alter ego cause of action is directly related to Sloanâ€™s cause of action for a declaratory judgment that Friends is a public body.Â  This second cause of action has no independent significance apart from the averments pertaining to the first cause of action.Â  Therefore, because we find the first cause of action moot, there is no necessity to address the issue of whether Friends is the alter ego of the Commission. 
IV.          
Laschâ€™s Entitlement to Summary Judgment 
Lasch argues as an additional sustaining ground that he is entitled to summary judgment because he is being sued only in his capacity as chairman of Friends.Â  We agree.
Because we find Sloanâ€™s causes of action against Friends moot, and neither the complaint nor issues on appeal contains any averments regarding Lasch beyond his capacity as chairman of Friends, we hold that Lasch is also entitled to summary judgment as to all issues on appeal. 
Conclusion
For the forgoing reasons, we affirm the ruling of the trial court granting summary judgment to Friends.Â  Additionally, we affirm the granting of summary judgment to Lasch.Â  However, we reverse the trial courtâ€™s finding that Sloan lacked standing to bring this action.
WALLER, BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice John W. Kittredge, concur.

[1] Â Friends contends that this issue is not properly before the Court. Friends argues that Sloan has only appealed the second trial courtâ€™s order, and that because the first trial court issued the order finding the declaratory judgment action moot, this issue is not presently reviewable by this Court.Â  While Friends is correct in the argument that the first trial courtâ€™s order is not before the Court, Friends fails to acknowledge that the first trial courtâ€™s order was amended to allow Sloan to go forward in his pursuit of a declaratory judgment in this cause of action.Â  Accordingly, we find the order issued by the second trial court is the order that declared the declaratory judgment cause of action moot. Therefore, this issue is properly before the Court.

title: Charleston County DSS v. King
description: This is a termination of parental rights case.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Charleston County Department of Social Services and John Roe and Mary Roe,
Intervenors, Petitioners,
v.
Pamela King, Kenneth King, Jr., and Cody King, a child, D/O/B- 03/24/97,
Defendants,
of whom Pamela King is, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal from Charleston County
Â FrancesÂ  P. Segars-Andrews, Family Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26152
Heard January 31, 2006 - Filed May 22, 2006Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
R. Glenn Lister, Jr., and Daphne A. Burns, of Mt. Pleasant; and FramptonÂ  Durban, Jr., of Charleston County Department of Social Services, of North Charleston, for petitioners.
Robert V. DeMarco, of Charleston, for respondent.
Ruth F. Buck, of Sullivans Island, for Amicus Curiae.
EllenÂ  Babb, of Mt. Pleasant, for Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE MOORE:Â  This petition arises out of a dispute over the termination of parental rights of a biological mother as to her youngest child.Â  The family court found the grounds were met for terminating the motherâ€™s parental rights and that doing so was in the best interests of the child.Â  The Court of Appeals reversed, upholding one ground for termination but finding the best interests of the child would be served by preserving the biological motherâ€™s parental rights.Â  Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. King, Op. No. 2005-UP-155 (S.C. Ct. App. filed March 4, 2005).[1]
Petitioners, Charleston County Department of Social Services (DSS) and the pre-adoptive parents of the child (the Kendles),[2] appeal the decision of the Court of Appeals.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Respondent, Pamela King (King), and her husband, Kenneth King, were arrested in October 1999, after attempting to pass a fraudulent check.Â  The couple and their three children were traveling through South Carolina from Pennsylvania and were moving to Texas to live near Kingâ€™s family.Â  The couple was arrested for obtaining goods under false pretenses.Â  Upon further inspection by police, a crack pipe was found in Kingâ€™s purse.[3] Â The
couple was placed in jail and DSS took the children into emergency protective custody.Â  At the time of removal, Casey was nine, Ashley was five, and Cody was two years old. 
A treatment plan was presented to the family court in January 2000 and finalized as of July 2000.Â  The plan directed King to undergo a psychological evaluation, complete parenting classes, complete various forms of counseling, and pay child support.
In February 2000, King and her husband moved from Charleston County to Jasper County.Â  King completed parenting classes in September 2000.Â  King attended counseling sessions, but then ceased to attend in April 2000.Â  She later attended more counseling sessions for approximately five months.Â  She paid six months of child support before her payments became sporadic.
King testified that, although she had never used drugs before, she began to use cocaine in October 2000.Â  She twice tested positive for cocaine in February and June 2001.Â  King testified she used cocaine two to three times a week from October 2000 to June 2001.Â  Meanwhile, in February 2001, King left her husband and moved in with her mother and stepfather in Smoaks, South Carolina.[4]Â  She resided there for approximately two years before the termination of parental rights (TPR) hearing and apparently continues to reside there with the two children who were returned to her.Â  At the time of the TPR hearing, King was in divorce proceedings with her estranged husband.Â  Throughout the time the children were in protective custody, King visited the children.
The Foster Care Review Board recommended terminating Kingâ€™s parental rights in October 2000.Â  Because King had not fully complied with her treatment plan, the family court adopted a permanence plan of
terminating Kingâ€™s parental rights as to all of her children in March 2001.Â  The TPR action was filed in May 2001. 
King, in the meantime, began to accomplish the goals set out in the treatment plan.Â  She entered substance abuse treatment, which included family counseling, through a Drug Court program following her September 2001 arrest for breach of trust.Â  She completed her substance abuse treatment in September 2002 and had completed all the requirements set out in the treatment plan except for paying child support, for which she was briefly imprisoned in March 2002.Â  She completed the anger management and domestic abuse counseling in March 2001 and the psychological evaluation in June 2001.Â  As a result, in April 2002, the Foster Care Review Board and the former guardian ad litem (GAL), Ruth Buck, changed their recommendations from termination of parental rights to reunification.Â  DSS looked at each childâ€™s individual best interest and returned Ashley and Casey, an autistic child, to King in November 2002.Â  DSS did not return Cody to King.Â  The DSS caseworker testified it was in Ashleyâ€™s and Caseyâ€™s best interests to be returned to King, but it was not in Codyâ€™s best interest to be returned to King.
As for the children, they were placed in separate foster homes after being removed from their parents.Â  Cody was placed with the Shanklin family for two years but was removed in September 2001.[5]Â  He was then placed in two short-term households before being placed in the pre-adoptive home of Kurtis and Gayle Kendle in October 2001.Â  When the Kendles took Cody in, the DSS caseworker informed them they could call him â€œCody Kendleâ€ and gave them a Medicaid card with the name â€œCody Kendle.â€Â  The caseworker also informed them they could raise him as their own son and represent themselves as his parents.Â  The caseworker stated that such actions are
standard practice for adoptive placements.Â  She testified she informed the Kendles that Cody was a high-risk adoption. 
When he was removed from the Kings, Cody was diagnosed with psychosocial dwarfism or psychosocial failure to thrive, an environmentally-induced condition that occurs when a child is not receiving appropriate nurturing behaviors from a parent.
DSS withdrew its action to terminate Kingâ€™s parental rights as to the older two children but continued with the action to terminate her rights as to Cody.Â  After a hearing, the family court judge terminated Kingâ€™s parental rights pursuant to three statutory grounds. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-1572 (2), (4), and (8) (Supp. 2005).Â  First, the court found King had failed to remedy the condition which caused the removal within six months following the adoption of the placement plan.Â  The family court judge also found King had failed to support her child by not paying child support in excess of six months.Â  Additionally, the family court found Cody had been in foster care for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months.
As for Codyâ€™s best interests, the family court found his best interests were served by terminating Kingâ€™s parental rights.Â  The court noted that, at that time, Cody had spent over half his life in foster care and was thriving with the Kendles.Â  The court found the evidence showed Cody did not have an accurate perception of his birth mother or siblings.Â  He viewed his siblings only as two children with whom he visits and King as Casey and Ashleyâ€™s mother.Â  The court also noted the overwhelming evidence that Cody had â€œbondedâ€ with the Kendles and referred to the Kendles as mom and dad.Â  The court distinguished Codyâ€™s situation from that of his siblings because, due to Codyâ€™s young age, he had essentially no memory of his biological family.
The Court of Appeals reversed, finding only one of the grounds for termination existed, and that Codyâ€™s best interests would be served by preserving Kingâ€™s parental rights.Â  The Court of Appeals found DSS had proved only one ground for TPR which was that Cody had been in foster care fifteen out of the most recent twenty-two months.Â  The Court of Appeals found it was in Codyâ€™s best interests to return to King and his siblings.Â  In finding for King, the Court of Appeals relied on the Moore factors (to be discussed infra), and determined that Codyâ€™s best interests would be served by denying the termination of Kingâ€™s parental rights.
The Court of Appealsâ€™ decision upholding the family courtâ€™s ruling that Cody had been in foster care fifteen out of the most recent twenty-two months at the time of the hearing was not appealed.Â  Because one statutory ground for TPR has been met, the only issue remaining for us to consider is whether termination is in the best interest of the child.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2005) (family court may terminate parental rights if it finds at least one of the nine statutory grounds for termination has been met and that termination is in the best interest of the child).
ISSUES

  
    
      
        I.
         Did the Court of Appeals err by applying the Moore v. Moore[6] criteria to a determination of the best interests of the child in a termination of parental rights case?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        II. 
         Did the Court of Appeals err by ruling that the best interests of the child required the parental rights of the mother to be preserved?
      
    
  

DISCUSSION
I
Petitioners argue the Court of Appeals erred by applying the Moore factors to a determination of the best interests of the child in a termination of parental rights case.Â  We agree.
The Moore case involved a child custody dispute between a natural father and the family that offered to take care of one of his five children.Â  The natural father accepted the familyâ€™s offer of taking care of the child, but continued to visit the child regularly.Â  Eventually, when the family refused to allow the father to visit with the child except in their home, the father commenced a suit requiring the family to show cause why he should not be allowed to remove the child from their home.
In Moore, we stated the dilemma is how to assure that parents who temporarily relinquish custody for their childâ€™s best interests can regain custody when conditions become more favorable.Â  To address this dilemma, we stated the following factors should be considered in making custody determinations when a natural parent seeks to reclaim custody of his child:Â  (1) the parent must prove that he or she is a fit parent, able to properly care for the child and provide a good home; (2) the amount of contact, in the form of visits, financial support or both, which the parent had with the child while the child was in the care of a third party; (3) the circumstances under which temporary relinquishment occurred; (4) the degree of attachment between the child and the temporary custodian.Â  After applying the criteria, we determined the natural father should be awarded custody of the child.
Petitioners argue the Moore factors were established to determine the best interests of a child in a custody dispute involving voluntary relinquishment of custody, not in a termination of parental rights action.Â  Petitioners are correct.
The Moore factors have been used in actions seeking to regain custody after a voluntary relinquishment.Â  See, e.g., Malpass v. Hodson, 309 S.C. 397, 424 S.E.2d 470 (1992) (factors used in case where mother sought to regain custody after voluntarily relinquishing custody to maternal grandparents Â while in abusive relationship); Dodge v. Dodge, 332 S.C. 401, 505 S.E.2d 344 (Ct. App. 1998) (factors used in case where father sought to regain custody after voluntarily relinquishing custody to grandparents).
We have used the Moore factors in one termination of parental rights case.Â  Hopkins v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 313 S.C. 322, 437 S.E.2d 542 (1993), overruled on other grounds by Joiner ex rel Rivas v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 536 S.E.2d 372 (2000).Â  However, this case is distinguishable.Â  Although a TPR action was involved, the target of that action was an innocent natural father who had attempted to establish his paternity of the child but could not because the mother continually disappeared with the child and later, without the fatherâ€™s knowledge, subjected the child to abuse and neglect.Â  While the child had not been voluntarily relinquished by the father as envisioned by the Moore case, DSS removed the child from the mother before the father was given a chance to establish his paternity; therefore, it was an action involving an innocent parent attempting to gain custody of his child from a third party.Â  Therefore, Hopkins, does not stand for the proposition that the Moore factors should be used when determining the best interests of a child in a termination of parental rights case.
The Court of Appeals has also mentioned the Moore factors in a TPR case.Â  In Shake, the parents of Michael voluntarily relinquished custody of him to the Department of Social Services (DSS) because he had been diagnosed with failure to thrive.Â  Shake v. Darlington County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 306 S.C. 216, 410 S.E.2d 923 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  DSS placed Michael with Shake and Shake later moved to terminate the parental rights of the parents and for custody of Michael regardless of termination of parental rights.Â  The court found DSS and Shake had failed to establish grounds sufficient to meet the standard required to terminate parental rights.Â  Therefore, the court found the motherâ€™s parental rights should not be terminated and did not reach the issue of whether the best interests of the child required that the motherâ€™s parental rights be terminated.
However, Shake further argued that even if parental rights were not terminated, it was in Michaelâ€™s best interest to remain in her custody.Â  The court utilized the Moore factors and determined that Michaelâ€™s best interests required that he be placed in Shakeâ€™s custody.Â  The Court of Appeals, therefore, did not apply the Moore factors to the termination of parental rights portion of the case but only to the custody portion of the case.
Accordingly, the Court of Appeals erred by applying the Moore factors to the instant action.Â  The Moore factors apply where a natural parent, who has voluntarily relinquished custody of his child, seeks to reclaim custody from a third party.Â  The Moore factors cannot apply in the termination of parental rights situation because that situation is governed by statute.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-1560 to -1582 (Supp. 2005).
II
Petitioners argue that because Cody has bonded with the Kendles, is thriving in their home, and has no memory of his biological mother and siblings, his best interests require that Kingâ€™s parental rights be terminated.
Both parties questioned the experts presented at trial regarding Codyâ€™s best interests.Â  Dr. Elizabeth Ralston, a clinical psychologist, testified she had observed Cody and the Kendles, and King and her other children. Â Dr. Ralston testified Cody had no verbal memory of his natural parents and did not identify King as his mother or Ashley and Casey as his siblings.Â  Instead, she testified Cody identifies King as â€œAshley and Caseyâ€™s motherâ€ and his siblings as â€œa boy and a girl, and as brother and sister.â€Â  In Dr. Ralstonâ€™s opinion, Cody has blossomed in the Kendlesâ€™ care and no longer shows any symptoms of psychosocial dwarfism.Â  On cross, Dr. Ralston testified Codyâ€™s removal from the Kendles might be mitigated by the fact that he was being returned to his natural mother and siblings if he had any memory of those people in that capacity.Â  However, she testified Cody does not have that memory. 
Dr. Charles Barton Saylor, a forensic psychologist, testified Cody did not express any recollection of his natural parents and did not have a real concept of his natural family.Â  He testified Cody thinks of Mrs. Kendle, not King, as his mother.Â  Dr. Saylor testified Codyâ€™s best interests would be served by allowing him to remain with the Kendles and have closure.
The DSS caseworker testified Cody is happy, bonded, and attached to the Kendles and has no real attachment to his mother during visits and that he mostly plays with his siblings during those visits.
One of the adoption specialists testified that Cody believes the Kendlesâ€™ home is his home and that he is comfortable there.Â  She felt his best interests required that he remain with the
Kendles.
The Kendles testified that Cody calls them mom and dad and is very affectionate towards them.Â  Mrs. Kendle, at the time of the hearing, was a stay-at-home mother and Mr. Kendle was a homebuilder working at an office inside the home.
The former GAL, Ruth Buck, testified Cody does not know King as his natural mother because he was too young when he was removed.Â  Buck stated she changed her position regarding TPR because King never missed a visit with Cody and she saw an improvement in Codyâ€™s relationship with her once the estranged husband stopped visiting.Â  She further changed her position because King made substantial progress on her treatment plan.Â  She admitted that Cody has bonded with the Kendles and calls them mom and dad and that Cody has a nice home to live in with a private room.Â  Buck testified that because King has been deemed to be a fit enough mother to take care of her special needs child, she is very able to accept Cody back into the family.Â  Buck recommended that Cody be returned to King.
When reviewing the family court decision, appellate courts may make their own conclusions of whether DSS proved by clear and convincing evidence that parental rights should be terminated.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cochran, 364 S.C. 621, 614 S.E.2d 642 (2005).Â  We have stated:Â  â€œThe termination of the legal relationship between natural parents and a child presents one [of] the most difficult issues this Court is called upon to decide.Â  We exercise great caution in reviewing termination proceedings and will conclude termination is proper only when the evidence clearly and convincingly mandates such a result.â€Â  Id.
at 626, 614 S.E.2d at 645.
Our General Assembly has mandated that when the interest of the child and the parental rights conflict, the interest of the child shall prevail. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp. 2005).Â  See also South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cochran, supra (in balancing the interests of the child and the mother, the best interest of the child is paramount to that of the parent).
At the time of the family court hearing, Cody had been out of Kingâ€™s care for almost three and one-half years and had been with the Kendles for almost one and a half years.Â  By the time King had completed her treatment plan, Cody was in a loving, stable environment with the Kendles and had no memory of his biological family.Â  As the experts at trial testified, Cody did not realize King was his natural mother and he identified the Kendles as his parents.Â  To remove Cody from the Kendles clearly would be very traumatic for him.Â  We find the family court correctly determined that the best interests of Cody were that his motherâ€™s parental rights be terminated and that he remain with the Kendles.Â  See Â§ 20-7-1578 (if the childâ€™s interest and the parental rights conflict, the interest of the child shall prevail). Â Accordingly, the decision of the Court of Appeals is
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Howard P. King, concur.

[1]Kenneth King, the biological father of the child, did not appeal the termination of his parental rights.
[2]Although the Kendles filed their motion to intervene under the pseudonyms John Roe and Mary Roe, they used their real names at the hearing.
[3]The charge regarding the crack pipe was dismissed.
[4]Kingâ€™s mother and step-father moved to South Carolina to assist their daughter in regaining her children.
[5]When Cody arrived at the Shanklin home, he was underweight, scared, cried for his brother, and had food issues.Â  He allegedly would eat until he made himself sick, hide food, and pick up objects and smell them to see if he could eat them.Â  Cody was removed from the Shanklin home when the Shanklins separated.
[6]300 S.C. 75, 386 S.E.2d 456 (1989).

title: Riddle v. Ozmint
description: The Court reversed a post-conviction relief order and granted a deathrow inmate a new trial.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Ernest Matthew Riddle, Petitioner,
v.
Jon Ozmint, Director, South Carolina Department of Corrections,
Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Cherokee County
Â J. Derham Cole, Post-Conviction Judge
James B. Stephen, Trial Judge

Opinion No. 26153
Heard February 1, 2006 - Filed May 22, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
Diana L. Holt and Teresa L. Norris, both of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Senior Assistant Attorney General William Edgar Salter, III, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  We granted certiorari to consider a post-conviction relief (PCR) order denying relief to petitioner, a death row inmate.Â  We find the solicitorâ€™s office violated Brady v. Maryland[1] when it suppressed certain evidence involving witness Jason Riddle (Jason), and that that office violated petitionerâ€™s due process rights when it failed to correct misstatements made by Jason while testifying against petitioner.Â  See Napue v. Illinois, 360 U.S. 264 (1959).Â  The PCR order denying petitioner relief is reversed, and the matter remanded for further proceedings. 
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In the early morning hours of August 8, 1985, Mrs. Abby Sue Mullinax was murdered in her home when her throat was cut.Â  Nineteen-year-old petitioner and his seventeen-year-old brother Jason were arrested on August 20, based on information supplied by their older brother, Bruce.Â  On August 22, Jason gave a statement confessing that he and petitioner[2] had entered the home through a window, that he had stolen money from a purse on a dresser, and that petitioner had cut Mrs. Mullinaxâ€™s throat.
Petitioner was convicted of the murder, burglary, and armed robbery of Abby Mullinax and received a death sentence.Â  There was no physical evidence connecting petitioner with the murder and robbery of Mrs. Mullinax.Â  Rather, the Stateâ€™s case rested on the eyewitness testimony of petitionerâ€™s alleged accomplice, his mildly mentally retarded brother Jason, and the testimony of various witnesses concerning petitionerâ€™s statements after Mrs. Mullinaxâ€™s death.
At the 1986 trial Jason testified against petitioner.Â  Bruce, who had been staying with Jimmy and Tammy Lewis in their home near Mrs. Mullinaxâ€™s, testified that petitioner had come to the Lewis home around 3 or 4 am on the 8th, panicky, covered with blood, and wet from the knees down.Â  Bruce testified that later that day Jason and petitioner were seen with cash, and that when a news story about the murder came on TV, petitioner said, â€œwe donâ€™t have to worry about that bitch anymore.â€Â  Tammy Lewis testified and confirmed Bruceâ€™s story about the money and petitionerâ€™s statement.
Fourteen-year-old Jerry Walker testified that several days after the murder petitioner said, in a joking manner, that he had killed a woman before.Â  Another witness, James Buster Smith, testified that he, Jerry, and petitioner had gone to a lake around August 12, and that petitioner told them he had known Mrs. Mullinax, and that she had had valuable possessions and money in her home.
Petitioner called his stepmother to testify that Bruce had admitted turning Jason and petitioner in for reward money.Â  Petitioner also called Clifton Coker, the Lewisâ€™s neighbor, who testified that shortly after the murder occurred he heard other neighbors Ricky and Lisa Nuzum (also spelled Newsome) up on his porch knocking on his door.Â  He then heard car doors slam as they drove away.Â  The next day he and his roommate found what appeared to be drops of blood on their porch.Â  They cleaned up the blood.Â  Bloodhounds taken to the Mullinax home â€œtrackedâ€ to the area around the Lewis-Nuzum-Coker homes and not to the barn.Â  Although the jury learned only that the State had used bloodhounds but not what trail they had followed, at the PCR hearing the State acknowledged that the dogs had tracked to the Lewis-Nuzum-Coker homes.
On appeal, the Court affirmed the murder conviction but set aside the death sentence.Â  State v. Riddle, 291 S.C. 232, 353 S.E.2d 138 (1987).Â  Following a 1987 resentencing proceeding, a second jury returned a death sentence, which was also reversed on direct appeal.Â  State v. Riddle, 301 S.C. 68, 389 S.E.2d 665 (1990).Â  In 1991, a third jury returned a death sentence which was affirmed.Â  Riddle v. State, 314 S.C. 1, 443 S.E.2d 557 (1994).[3]
This PCR action involves the guilt phase of the 1986 trial and the 1991 resentencing proceeding.Â  We address only the grave constitutional violations which occurred during the 1986 guilt phase, and which mandate reversal of the PCR order.
ISSUES

  
    
      
        1)  
         Whether there is any evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that no Brady violation occurred?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        2) 
         Whether the PCR judge erred in concluding that the Solicitorâ€™s failure to correct Jasonâ€™s false trial testimony did not require a new trial?
      
    
  

Scope of Review
On certiorari, this Court must uphold the PCR judgeâ€™s findings where they are supported by any evidence of probative value in the record.Â  Gibson v. State, 344 S.C. 515, 514 S.E.2d 320 (1999).Â  We are concerned here not with the routine PCR issue whether trial counsel was ineffective, but instead with the question whether prosecutorial misconduct denied petitionerâ€™s due process right to a fair trial.Â  Id.
1.     Brady violation
An individual asserting a Brady violation must demonstrate that evidence: (1) favorable to the accused; (2) in the possession of or known by the prosecution; (3) was suppressed by the State; and (4) was material to the accusedâ€™s guilt or innocence or was impeaching.Â  Kyles v. Whitley, 514 U.S. 419 (1995); Gibson, supra.Â  If a Brady violation is found to have occurred, PCR must be granted.Â  Gibson, supra.Â  Petitioner points to several instances of alleged Brady violations.Â  We find it necessary to discuss only two.
First, as noted above, Jason gave a statement confessing to his and petitionerâ€™s guilt on August 22, 1985.Â  The first trial commenced on January 27, 1986.Â  On January 22, 1986, Jason gave a second statement to police which petitioner contends was not disclosed to his attorneys.Â  The PCR judge found that had petitionerâ€™s counsel interviewed the officer who took notes of the statement between January 22 and the start of the trial, they would have learned of this statement.Â  The PCR judge therefore concluded that the January 22 statement was available to petitioner, and thus the Stateâ€™s failure to disclose this statement did not violate Brady.Â  We disagree.Â  Not only is it unrealistic to require petitioner and his attorneys to reinterview all officers and investigators in the days before the trial, but that is not what Brady requires.Â  The burden is on the solicitor to disclose material evidence which is exculpatory or impeaching.Â  Gibson, supra.
The PCR judge also held that nothing in Jasonâ€™s January 22 statement was material for Brady impeachment purposes.Â  Evidence is material under Brady if there is a â€œreasonable probabilityâ€ that the result of the proceeding would have been different had the information been disclosed.Â  E.g., State v. Proctor, 358 S.C. 424, 595 S.E.2d 480 (2004).Â  The question is not whether petitioner would more likely have been acquitted had this evidence been disclosed, but whether, without this impeachment evidence, he received a fair trial â€œresulting in a verdict worthy of confidence.â€Â  Kyles v. Whitley, supra, at 434.
There were several inconsistencies between Jasonâ€™s original statement and his trial testimony, and the undisclosed January 22 statement.Â  Among these differences were whether Jason or petitioner removed the window fan from the window before entering the home; whether the brothers both went to the bedroom or whether one went to the kitchen and the other to the bedroom; whether the victimâ€™s purse was found on a large or small dresser; whether Jason fell before or after he heard the victim getting up, and where he fell; where he was when he saw petitioner kill Mrs. Mullinax; what he saw or heard as he left the house; and whether they got $100 or $125.
The most glaring inconsistency is that in his January 22 statement, Jason claimed that a friend had picked the brothers up after the murder and given them a ride to the barn, whereas in his original statement and in his trial testimony he maintained the brothers had walked the approximately three miles from the Mullinax home to the barn.Â  Before the commencement of the trial, officers questioned the person Jason identified as having given the brothers a ride, who denied having done so. Â The State therefore chose not to present any evidence of the brothers having been driven to the barn.
The impeachment value of this statement is clear.Â  Either the brothers were given a lift or they were not: Jason could not have been telling the truth in all his statements.Â  Moreover, without the automobile ride, it is difficult to conceive how the brothers were able to travel the three miles from the Mullinax home to the barn, and back to the Lewisâ€™s home, in the time between the murder and the time when Bruce testified they returned to the Lewis home.
Whether this statement alone was material under Brady is a close question.Â  As we stated in Gibson, citing the United States Supreme Court:

The overriding theme of the Brady cases is the emphasis the Supreme Court has placed on the prosecutorâ€™s responsibility for fair play.Â  In close cases, â€œthe prudent prosecutor will resolve doubtful questions in favor of disclosure.Â  This is as it should be.Â  Such disclosures will serve to justify trust in the prosecutor as the representativeâ€¦of a sovereigntyâ€¦whose interestâ€¦in a criminal prosecution is not that it shall win a case, but that justice shall be done.Â  And it will tend to preserve the criminal trial, as distinct from the prosecutorâ€™s private deliberations, as the chosen forum for ascertaining the truth about criminal accusations.â€
Kyles v. Whitley, 514 U.S. at 438-40 (quotes omitted) (citing Berger v. United States, 295 U.S. 78, 88 (1935)).

Our judicial system relies upon the integrity of the participants.Â  State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 527 S.E.2d 105 (2000).Â  In this case, a prudent solicitor would have chosen to disclose the January 22 questioning and the resulting statement.
When determining whether the suppression of more than one item of evidence was material under Brady, we consider the collective impact of the undisclosed evidence.Â  Kyles v. Whitley, 514 U.S. at 436.Â  The second undisclosed evidentiary item in this case was the fact that on January 24, 1986, two days after Jasonâ€™s second statement and three days before the trial commenced, several police officers, Solicitor Gossett, and the solicitorâ€™s assistant took Jason by automobile to the Mullinax home and from there retraced the route he and Ernest took to the barn.Â  There were questions asked of Jason during this outing, although it is unclear whether any new information was gleaned.Â  The defense was not informed of this trip. 
The PCR judge concluded, among other things, that information relating to the trip was in the prosecutorâ€™s file and therefore available to the defense under the solicitorâ€™s â€œopen fileâ€ policy.Â  The evidence at trial, however, was that the solicitorâ€™s office maintained an unusual â€œopen fileâ€ policy in that they removed not only work product, but also â€œother documents on a case-by-case basis.â€Â  Even had a true â€œopen fileâ€ policy existed, the existence of such a policy does not negate the solicitorâ€™s Brady obligation. Â Porter v. State, Op. No. _________ (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed March 6, 2006).Â  This is especially so where the â€œreconstructionâ€ trip took place only three days before trial.
Jason was a young man of limited mental abilities: knowledge of this trip would have bolstered petitionerâ€™s contention that Jason was an unreliable witness who had to be coached, and whose testimony was not worthy of belief.Â  Given the absence of any physical evidence tying petitioner to the Mullinax murder, the Stateâ€™s case rested almost exclusively on Jasonâ€™s recounting. 
Â The PCR judgeâ€™s finding that the evidence of the January 22nd statement and the January 24 trip was not material under Brady is without evidentiary support in the record, and therefore is reversed.
3)     Failure to correct false testimony
At the 1986 trial, Jason was asked more than once whether he had spoken about the case to anyone other than Officer Harris in August 1985 when he gave his first statement.Â  Jason denied speaking with anyone other than his lawyers, neglecting to mention either the January 22, 1986 statement or the trip on January 24, 1986. Â The solicitor failed to correct Jasonâ€™s false trial testimony.
The PCR judge found that the State did not violate due process by failing to correct Jasonâ€™s false testimony because the State may have thought either that Jason misunderstood the questions or that he simply did not recall the recent events.Â  Since the State did not know why Jason failed to testify truthfully, petitioner was found not to have met his burden of showing the State knowingly used perjured testimony.
We disagree.Â  The issue is not why Jason failed to tell the truth: rather, it is why the solicitor, who knew Jasonâ€™s testimony to be false, failed to correct it.
A "prosecutorâ€™s deliberate deception of a court and jurors by the presentation of known false evidence is incompatible with rudimentary demands of justice.â€Â  Giglio v. U.S., 405 U.S. 150, 153 (1972).Â  The failure to correct false evidence is as reprehensible as its presentation.Â  Washington v. State, 324 S.C. 232, 478 S.E.2d 833 (1996).Â  The PCR judge erred in concluding that the State was not obligated to correct Jasonâ€™s false testimony, and in failing to hold that this violation of petitionerâ€™s due process rights required that he be granted a new trial.
CONCLUSION
The Constitution requires only that a defendant receive a fair trial, not a perfect one.Â  U.S. Const. Am. VI; State v. Johnson, 334 S.C. 78, 512 S.E.2d 795 (1999).Â  Petitionerâ€™s trial was rendered fundamentally unfair by prosecutorial misconduct.Â  No probative evidence exists in this record to support the PCR judgeâ€™s findings and conclusion.Â  Accordingly, the PCR order denying petitioner relief is 
 REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Brooks P. Goldsmith, concur.

[1] 373 U.S. 83 (1963).
[2] Years later Jason would recant petitionerâ€™s involvement and name Bruce as his accomplice.
[3] All three circuit court proceedings were prosecuted by then-Solicitor Holman A. Gossett, Jr, while petitioner was represented in all trial proceedings by Kenneth L. Holland.

title: Palmetto Princess v. Georgetown County
description: This case involves the issue of whether the circuit court erred by finding Georgetown County exceeded its authority in passing ordinances that prevented a gambling day cruise business.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Palmetto Princess, LLC, Respondent,
v.
Georgetown County, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26154
Heard February 14, 2006 - Filed May 22, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jack M. Scoville, Jr., and John McIntyre Tolar, of Georgetown; William B. Regan and Frances I. Cantwell, of Regan and Cantwell, LLC, of Charleston, for appellant.
A. Camden Lewis and Arial E. King, both of Lewis, Babcock & Hawkins, LLP, of Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE MOORE:Â  This is an appeal from a circuit court order granting respondentâ€™s (Palmetto Princessâ€™s) motion for summary judgment.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In April 2004, Palmetto Princess brought a declaratory judgment action against appellant, Georgetown County (the County), on the grounds the County had exceeded its authority in passing two ordinances and that the ordinances violated the South Carolina Constitution.Â  Palmetto Princess brought the action because it intended to run a gambling day cruise, also known as a â€œcruise to nowhere,â€ out of the County, and the Countyâ€™s ordinances prevented such a business.
The Countyâ€™s first ordinance, Ordinance # 2002-12, provides, in pertinent part:

No person shall open, keep, maintain, dock, moor, anchor or operate any gaming vessel within the corporate limits of the County, or suffer any gaming vessel to operate from any marina, terminal or marine facility within the corporate limits of the County for the purpose of embarking or disembarking persons whose intent is to use gambling devices or gambling facilities within the vessel.
. . .
Anyone violating this ordinance shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by the payment of a fine of up to five hundred dollars and be sentenced to a term of imprisonment of up to thirty days in jail.

The Countyâ€™s second ordinance, Ordinance # 2004-11, provides, in pertinent part:

The manufacture, reconditioning, repair, sale, transportation, possession or use of any gambling device on any vessel on a day cruise is prohibited.
. . .
 Section 2.Â Â  By enacting this ordinance, County Council under the authority delegated to it by the South Carolina Legislature in S.C. Code Ann. Section 4-9-25, exercises the authority granted the State of South Carolina by the Congress of the United States in 15 U.S.C. Section 1175(b)(2)(A)[1] and declares that Georgetown County is exempt from the provisions of 15 U.S.C. Section 1175(b)(1).
 Section 3.Â Â  This civil prohibition is adopted for the sole objective of having gambling day cruises remain a federal offense within Georgetown County, under 15 U.S.C. Section 1175, and not for the purpose of rendering such conduct a misdemeanor penalized under state law, and such prosecution is hereby prohibited.

Both parties filed for summary judgment.Â  The circuit court granted Palmetto Princessâ€™s motion for summary judgment based on two grounds.Â  First, the court held the plain language of the Johnson Act makes clear that the authority to declare gambling day cruises illegal is vested with a State and not a county.Â  Therefore, the County was without authority to enact the ordinances.Â  Second, the court found that the ordinances violate article VIII, Â§ 14, of the state constitution because the ordinances make conduct illegal that is not illegal under state law.
ISSUE

Did the circuit court err by finding the County had exceeded its authority in passing the ordinances?Â  

DISCUSSION
The County argues it has authority to opt out of the Johnson Act and enact an ordinance prohibiting gambling day cruises.Â  The County contends the Johnson Act allows a local government, rather than just a state government, to enact a law prohibiting gambling day cruises.
The Johnson Act generally prohibits the use or possession of any gambling device on a United States flag vessel.Â  One exception is that the possession or transport of a gambling device within state territorial waters is not a violation of the prohibition if the device remains on board the vessel and is used only outside those territorial waters.Â  15 U.S.C. Â§ 1175(b)(1).Â  That exception does not apply, however, â€œif the State or possession of the United States in which the voyage or segment begins and ends has enacted a statuteâ€ prohibiting gambling day cruises.Â  15 U.S.C. Â§ 1175(b)(2)(A) (emphasis added).
The circuit court correctly held that the plain language of the Johnson Act indicates that only a State, not a division of the state government such as the County here, can act to prohibit gambling day cruises.Â  See Brown v. County of Berkeley, 366 S.C. 354, 622 S.E.2d 533 (2005) (clear and unambiguous words in a statute should be given their plain and ordinary meaning).Â  The Countyâ€™s alleged power to enact the ordinances, therefore, cannot derive from the Johnson Act.Â  We further note that, at the time the ordinances were enacted, the State had not opted out of the Johnson Act and had not enacted a statute prohibiting gambling day cruises.[2]Â  See Stardancer Casino, Inc. v. Stewart, 347 S.C. 377, 556 S.E.2d 357 (2001) (gambling day cruises are not unlawful).
CONCLUSION
We conclude the plain language of the Johnson Act indicates that only a State, not a division of the state government such as the County here, can act to prohibit gambling day cruises.Â  Therefore, the circuit court properly granted summary judgment to Palmetto Princess.Â  See Cunningham ex rel. Grice v. Helping Hands, Inc., 352 S.C. 485, 575 S.E.2d 549 (2003) (summary judgment appropriate only if there is no genuine issue of material fact and moving party is entitled to judgment as matter of law).Â  Given our decision, it is unnecessary to address the Countyâ€™s argument that the circuit court erred by finding its ordinances violated article VIII, Â§14, of the South Carolina Constitution.Â  See Hagood v. Sommerville, 362 S.C. 191, 607 S.E.2d 707 (2005) (appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).Â  Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., BURNETT, J., and Acting Justices James W. Johnson, Jr., and Mark J. Hayes, II, concur.

[1]Also known as the Johnson Act, to be discussed infra.
[2]Subsequent to the circuit courtâ€™s order issued in this case, the General Assemblyâ€™s Gambling Cruise Prohibition Act was signed into law by the governor with an effective date of June 1, 2005.Â  Section 3-11-200(A) of this Act specifically allows the type of ordinance enacted by the County.

The Supreme Court of South Carolina
Casey C. Lewis, Petitioner
v.
 State of South Carolina, Respondent.

ORDER

By order dated January 30, 2006, the circuit court issued a conditional order of dismissal in this post-conviction relief case. This order gave petitioner twenty days to show cause why the conditional order should not become final. Instead of filing a reply to this conditional order of dismissal, petitioner has filed a petition for a writ of certiorari with this Court, which we have construed as a notice of appeal.
Under Rule 227, SCACR, and S.C. Code Ann. § 17-27-100 (2003), only a final decision or judgment in a post-conviction relief action is subject to review. "Any judgment or decree, leaving some further act to be done by the court before the rights of the parties are determined, is interlocutory; but if it so completely fixes the rights of the parties that the court has nothing further to do in the action, then it is final." Adickes v. Allison & Bratton, 21 S.C. 245 (1884); see also Mid-State Distributors, Inc. v. Century Importers, Inc., 310 S.C. 330, 426 S.E.2d 777 (1993).
 
In our opinion, a conditional order of dismissal is not the final judgment in a post-conviction relief case since there is another act to be done before the rights of the parties are finally determined – the issuance of an order following the filing of a reply or the issuance of an order based on the default in filing a reply. S.C. Code Ann. § 17-27-70 (b) (2003). Accordingly, this matter is dismissed without prejudice.
