title: State v. Rayfield
description: The Court granted a writ of certiorari to review State v. Rayfield, 357 S.C. 497, 593 S.E.2d 486 (Ct. App. 2004).  The Court determined the Court of Appeals properly found the trial judge committed harmless error in granting the Stateâ€™s Batson motion and redrawing the petit jury.  The majority of the Court held the Court of Appeals also properly found the trial judge did not err in charging the jury that the victimâ€™s testimony need not be corroborated by other testimony or evidence.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Bynum Rayfield, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Chester County
Â Paul E. Short, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26155
Heard November 3, 2005 - Filed May 30, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jack B. Swerling, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, and Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia, and Solicitor John R. Justice, of Chester, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in State v. Rayfield, 357 S.C. 497, 593 S.E.2d 486 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Bynum Rayfield (Petitioner) was convicted of three counts of first-degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor, three counts of committing a lewd act upon a child, and one count of contributing to the delinquency of a minor.Â  Petitioner was sentenced to concurrent terms of imprisonment of thirty years for CSC, fifteen years for lewd acts, and three years for contributing to delinquency.Â  
During the initial jury selection, Petitioner exercised peremptory challenges against five members of the jury venire: Â five white females, one of whom was a potential alternate, and one white male.Â  The petit jury selected was composed of nine males and three females.Â  The alternates were one male and one female.
After the jury was selected, the State moved the court pursuant to Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79, 106 S.Ct. 1712, 90 L.Ed.2d 69 (1986), to find that Petitioner had exercised his peremptory challenges based on gender.[1]Â  The Stateâ€™s main argument was that Petitioner had discriminatorily challenged female jurors, but the State also argued that Petitioner had discriminatorily challenged one male juror, the only male he challenged.
The trial judge found no Batson violation with respect to the female jurors.Â  The trial judge did find a violation with respect to the one male, Juror # 70; therefore, the judge granted the Stateâ€™s motion and redrew the jury.Â  None of the jurors initially challenged by Petitioner was selected for the second jury.Â  No Batson motion was made, and the second jury served at trial. 
Later, during the hearing on requests to charge, Petitioner objected to the trial judge charging the jury that under South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ Â 16-3-657 (2003), â€œthe testimony of a victim need not be corroborated in prosecutionsâ€ for CSC with a minor.Â  Petitioner argued that the charge improperly implies that the alleged victimâ€™s testimony is more credible than other witnessesâ€™ testimony.Â  The trial judge disagreed and gave the charge.Â Â  
After the jury returned with guilty verdicts, Petitioner moved for a new trial based both on the trial judgeâ€™s redrawing of the jury and on the charge to the jury.Â  The judge court denied the motion on both grounds.
Petitioner appealed the convictions and the Court of Appeals affirmed.Â  The Court of Appeals held that the trial judge had erred in granting the Stateâ€™s Batson motion, because â€œno gender based discrimination was associated with the striking ofâ€ the one male juror.Â  Rayfield, 357 S.C. at 503, 593 S.E.2d at 490.Â  The Court of Appeals further held, however, that the trial judgeâ€™s error was harmless because none of the jurors whom Petitioner excused from the original jury served on the trial jury.Â  Id. at 504, 593 S.E.2d at 490.Â  According to the Court of Appeals, its holding was required under our opinion in State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 470 S.E.2d 366 (1996).Â  Id.
With respect to the jury charge, the Court of Appeals held that the trial judge had committed no error.Â  The Court of Appeals noted that the no-corroboration charge withstood appellate scrutiny in State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 435 S.E.2d 859 (1993).Â  Rayfield, 357 S.C. at 505, 593 S.E.2d at 491.Â  The Court of Appeals held that the charge as a whole was proper.Â  Id.
ISSUES

I.Â  Did the Court of Appeals err in holding that the trial judge, in granting a groundless Batson motion by the State, committed harmless error in quashing the original jury and drawing a new one?
II.Â  Did the Court of Appeals err in holding that the trial judge properly charged Section 16-3-657 to the jury?

LAW AND ANALYSIS
I.Â  BATSON MOTION
Petitioner argues the Court of Appeals erred in holding that, although the trial judge erred in granting the Stateâ€™s groundless Batson motion, Petitioner failed to demonstrate he was prejudiced by the error.Â  Allowing the State to pursue a meritless Batson motion as a strategic ploy to draw a jury more to its liking is inconsistent with the Stateâ€™s duty to ensure that justice is done even while striving vigorously to obtain a conviction.Â  Petitioner contends he was unfairly prejudiced due to the improper advantage gained by the State and, in any event, he should not be required to demonstrate prejudice in this instance because any remedy short of a new trial rewards the State for using an improper trial tactic.
â€œThe Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits the striking of a venire person on the basis of race or gender.â€Â  State v. Shuler, 344 S.C. 604, 615, 545 S.E.2d 805, 810 (2001).Â  â€œThe purposes of Batson and its progeny are to protect the defendantâ€™s right to a fair trial by a jury of the defendantâ€™s peers, protect each venirepersonâ€™s right not to be excluded from jury service for discriminatory reasons, and preserve public confidence in the fairness of our system of justice by seeking to eradicate discrimination in the jury selection process.â€Â  State v. Haigler, 334 S.C. 623, 628-29, 515 S.E.2d 88, 90 (1999).Â  Both the State and defendants are prohibited from discriminatorily exercising a peremptory challenge of a prospective juror.Â  Georgia v. McCollum, 505 U.S. 42, 58, 112 S.Ct. 2348, 2358-59, 120 L.Ed.2d 33 (1992).
We set forth the proper procedure for a Batson hearing in State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 470 S.E.2d 366 (1996) (citing Purkett v. Elem, 514 U.S. 765, 115 S.Ct. 1769, 131 L.Ed.2d 834 (1995)).Â  After a party objects to a jury strike, the proponent of the strike must offer a facially race-neutral explanation. Â This explanation is not required to be persuasive or even plausible. Â Once the proponent states a reason that is race-neutral, the burden is on the party challenging the strike to show the explanation is mere pretext, either by showing similarly situated members of another race were seated on the jury or the reason given for the strike is so fundamentally implausible as to constitute mere pretext despite a lack of disparate treatment.Â  Adams, 322 S.C. at 123-24, 470 S.E.2d at 371-72; Haigler, 334 S.C. at 629-30, 515 S.E.2d at 90-91.Â  
The Court of Appeals correctly held that the trial judge erred in granting the Stateâ€™s meritless Batson motion and redrawing the jury.Â  The record contains no evidence Petitioner struck the male juror based on gender.Â  During the Batson hearing, Petitioner gave a gender-neutral explanation for the strike: Â the juror had a conservative appearance and was retired.Â  E.g. State v. Wilder, 306 S.C. 535, 538, 413 S.E.2d 323, 325 (1991) (party may strike potential juror based on demeanor and disposition); Haigler, 334 S.C. 632, 515 S.E.2d at 92 (lack of employment or place of employment may be neutral reason for strike).Â  The record does not reveal a pattern of striking male jurors or any other evidence to support a finding that Petitionerâ€™s explanation was a pretext.Â  Petitioner struck only one out of ten prospective male jurors.Â  As the Court of Appeals observed, the State took a â€œdisjointed and moving-target approach to its Batson motion.â€Â  Rayfield, 357 S.C. at 503, 593 S.E.2d at 489.Â  We agree with Petitioner that it appears the State willfully made a meritless Batson motion for the sole purpose of seeking a second chance to draw a jury which might look more favorably upon the Stateâ€™s case.
Nevertheless, we conclude the Court of Appeals correctly held the trial judgeâ€™s error was harmless.Â  In Adams, we held that when the trial judge improperly quashes a jury panel, no jurorâ€™s equal protection rights are violated because no Batson violation has occurred.Â  Adams, 322 S.C. at 125-26, 470 S.E.2d at 373.Â  We further held that if the jury which actually serves at trial is not tainted by an erroneous Batson ruling in favor of the prosecution, then the defendantâ€™s right to a fair trial is not violated because a defendant does not have a right to be tried by any particular jury.Â  Consequently, we held that the judgeâ€™s erroneous Batson ruling was harmless error.Â  Id. at 126, 470 S.E.2d at 373; see also State v. Wright, 304 S.C. 529, 534, 405 S.E.2d 825, 828 (1991) (concluding there was no prejudice to defendant when, despite earlier erroneous rulings by trial judge, he received what Batson was intended to provide).
We have held that a defendant need not always show actual prejudice for an erroneous Batson ruling to be reversible.Â  Unlike Adams and the present case, however, those cases involved erroneous Batson rulings which actually tainted the jury which served at trial.Â  See State v. Ford, 334 S.C. 59, 63-66, 512 S.E.2d 500, 503-04 (1999) (defendant was not required to show actual prejudice stemming from judgeâ€™s erroneous granting of Stateâ€™s Batson motion because, during selection of second jury, defendant was wrongfully denied the right to exercise a peremptory challenge against one or more jurors he previously had struck for racially neutral reasons); State v. Short, 333 S.C. 473, 476-78, 511 S.E.2d 358, 360-61 (1999) (applying same principle under similar facts); State v. Floyd, 353 S.C. 55, 58-59 & n. 5, 577 S.E.2d 215, 216 & n. 5 (2003) (defendant was not required to show actual prejudice stemming from judgeâ€™s erroneous excusal of juror who refused to take a religious oath).Â  Prejudice is presumed in such cases because there is no way to determine with any degree of certainty whether a defendantâ€™s right to a fair trial by an impartial jury was abridged.Â  Short, 333 S.C. at 476-77, 511 S.E.2d at 360.
In the present case, the second jury was not tainted by the trial judgeâ€™s erroneous Batson ruling.Â  No juror whom Petitioner challenged in the initial drawing was selected to serve on the trial jury.Â  The Court of Appeals properly held this case is controlled by Adams, and Petitioner must show actual prejudice for the trial judgeâ€™s error to be reversible.Â  Petitioner may not have received the jury he wanted, but as we held in Adams, a defendant has no right to a particular jury.Â  For these reasons, we conclude the trial judgeâ€™s erroneous quashing of the original jury and the drawing of a new one constitutes harmless error.
In reaching our conclusion, we emphasize it is improper for a party to assert a groundless Batson motion as a tactic to gain a second shot at selecting another jury panel which the party believes might look more favorably upon his case.Â  We admonish counsel for the State that abuses such as the meritless motion in this case are looked upon with disfavor and will not be countenanced in the future.Â  The solicitor and defense counsel are officers of a court of law, and are expected and required to have lawful and reasonable bases for motions presented to the trial judge.Â  Moreover, a solicitor

should bear in mind that he is an officer of the court, who represents all the people, including [the] accused, and [he] occupies a quasi-judicial position, whose sanctions and traditions he should preserve. Â It is his duty to see that justice is done. Â He must see that no conviction takes place except in strict conformity with the law, and that [the] accused is not deprived of any constitutional rights or privileges. Â However strong the prosecuting attorneyâ€™s belief may be of the prisonerâ€™s guilt, it is his duty to conduct the trial in such a manner as will be fair and impartial to the rights of the accused, . . . and not say or do anything which might improperly affect or influence the jury or [the] accusedâ€™s counsel.

State v. King, 222 S.C. 108, 119, 71 S.E.2d 793, 798 (1952).Â  â€œThis Court, on numerous occasions, has held that the duty of a solicitor is not to convict a defendant, but to see that justice is done.Â  At the same time, the solicitor should prosecute vigorously.â€Â  State v. Durden, 264 S.C. 86, 92, 212 S.E.2d 587, 590 (1975); accord Berger v. United States, 295 U.S. 78, 88, 55 S.Ct. 629, 633, 79 L.Ed. 1314 (1935) (federal prosecutor â€œis the representative not of an ordinary party to a controversy, but of a sovereignty whose obligation to govern impartially is as compelling as its obligation to govern at all; and whose interest, therefore, in a criminal prosecution is not that it shall win a case, but that justice shall be doneâ€).
II.Â  JURY INSTRUCTION
Petitioner argues the trial judge erred in charging South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-657 (2003) to the jury because the charge constitutes an impermissible comment on the facts of the case, it improperly emphasizes the testimony of one witness, and it carries a strong possibility of unfairly biasing the jury against the defendant.Â  Petitioner contends the Court of Appeals erred in relying on State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 435 S.E.2d 859 (1993) to find the instruction was permissible.Â  We disagree and conclude the Court of Appeals properly relied on Schumpert in holding the trial judge did not err in charging the jury that the victimâ€™s testimony need not be corroborated by other testimony or evidence. 
Petitioner was charged with three counts of first-degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor, in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-655 (2003).Â  A related statute, Â§ 16-3-657, provides â€œ[t]he testimony of the victim need not be corroborated in prosecutions under Â§Â§ 16-3-652 through 16-3-658.â€Â  These statutes prohibit various forms of criminal sexual conduct.Â  In Schumpert, we held it was not error to charge Â§ 16-3-657 as long as the charge as a whole comports with the law.Â  Schumpert, 312 S.C. at 509, 435 S.E.2d at 863.
The trial judge in the present case instructed the jury in accordance with the statute, stating â€œÂ§ 16-3-657 of our code of laws provides that the testimony of a victim need not be corroborated in prosecutions under this section.â€Â  The trial judge charged the jury the State had the burden of proving Petitioner was guilty of the charged offenses beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  The trial judge further instructed the jury:

In every case tried in this court before a jury, the jury becomes the sole and exclusive judges of the facts of the case.Â  You, the ladies and gentlemen of this trial jury, are the sole and exclusive judges of the facts in this case.Â  The constitution of the state of South Carolina has declared that a trial judge shall not intimate, state, comment upon, or make any statement to a trial jury about the facts in a case.
Since you are the sole and exclusive judges of the facts in this case, ladies and gentlemen, you are not to infer anything that I have said during the progress of this trial in ruling upon the admissibility of the evidence or from anything that I now say to you during the course of my charge to you that I have an opinion about the facts in this case.Â  Ladies and gentlemen, the law does not permit me to have an opinion about the facts in this case.Â  That is a matter solely for you, the ladies and gentlemen of the trial jury, to determine.
As jurors, then, it is your duty to determine, as I have stated to you, the effect, the value, the weight, and the truth of the evidence presented during the course of this trial.Â  Necessarily, then, ladies and gentlemen, you must assess the credibility of the witnesses who have testified in this case.Â  Credibility is simply a legalistic word which means believability.Â  It becomes your duty as jurors to analyze and to evaluate the evidence and to determine that evidence which convinces you of its truth.
I charge you in determining the question of the credibility or the believability of the witnesses, you may believe one witness as against several witnesses or several witnesses as against one witness.Â  You may believe a part of the testimony of a witness and reject the remaining part of the testimony of that same witness.Â  You may believe the testimony of a witness in its entirety or you may reject the testimony of a witness in its entirety.
You may consider whether any witness has exhibited any interest, any bias, or any prejudice in this case.Â  And, ladies and gentlemen, you may consider the demeanor of a witness, that is, the appearance of the witness on this witness stand during the trial of this case, and you may consider the opportunity for knowledge concerning those things about which a witness has testified.
These considerations you do not exercise arbitrarily, but if, in your good judgment, there is sound reason in the record of this case for so doing, because your objective, ladies and gentlemen, is to find the truth, whether it come from witness or witnesses for the state of South Carolina or from witness or witnesses for the defendant, and in so doing, in exercising your mental processes and in determining what you consider to be true, ladies and gentlemen, our law simply requires that you exercise your good, common sense, your good judgment, your sense of logic and reason, and your experiences in life.

It is not always necessary, of course, to charge the contents of a current statute.Â  Section 16-3-657 prevents trial or appellate courts from finding a lack of sufficient evidence to support a conviction simply because the alleged victimâ€™s testimony is not corroborated.Â  However, Â§ 16-3-657 does much more.Â  In enacting this statute, the Legislature recognized that crimes involving criminal sexual conduct fall within a unique category of offenses against the person.Â  In many cases, the only witnesses to a rape or sexual assault are the perpetrator and the victim.Â  An investigation may or may not reveal physical or forensic evidence identifying a particular perpetrator.Â  The Legislature has decided it is reasonable and appropriate in criminal sexual conduct cases to make abundantly clear - not only to the judge but also to the jury - that a defendant may be convicted solely on the basis of a victimâ€™s testimony.
A trial judge is not required to charge Â§ 16-3-657, but when the judge chooses to do so, giving the charge does not constitute reversible error when this single instruction is not unduly emphasized and the charge as a whole comports with the law.Â  The jury in this case was thoroughly instructed on the Stateâ€™s burden of proof and the juryâ€™s duty to find the facts and judge the credibility of witnesses.Â  The trial judge in this case, as shown in the above portions of the charge, fully and properly instructed the jury on these principles.
CONCLUSION
We conclude the Court of Appeals correctly held that the trial judge erred in granting the Stateâ€™s meritless Batson motion and redrawing the jury.Â  While we conclude the error was harmless because the second jury was not tainted by the erroneous Batson ruling, we emphasize it is improper for a party to assert a groundless Batson motion as a tactic to gain a second shot at selecting another jury panel which the party believes might look more favorably upon his case.Â  We further conclude the Court of Appeals properly held the trial judge did not err in charging the jury that the victimâ€™s testimony need not be corroborated by other testimony or evidence. 
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., and WALLER, J., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., concurring in part, dissenting in part in a separate opinion in which Acting Justice Stephen S. Bartlett, concurs.
 JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I concur in the majority opinionâ€™s holding that the circuit courtâ€™s Batson ruling constituted harmless error under State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 470 S.E.2d 366 (1996).Â  I respectfully dissent from the majority opinionâ€™s holding that the circuit court committed no error in charging the jury.Â  In my opinion, the circuit court committed reversible error, and Petitioner is entitled to a new trial.
Petitioner was charged with three counts of first-degree CSC with a minor, in violation of South Carolina Code section 16-3-655.[2]Â  Another statute, section 16-3-657,[3] provides that â€œ[t]he testimony of the victim need not be corroborated in prosecutions under Â§Â§ 16-3-652 through 16-3-658.â€Â  The circuit court charged the jury the above quoted language of section 16-3-657. Â This was reversible error.Â  
â€œIn general, the trial court is required to charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina. ... A jury charge is correct if it contains the correct
definition of the law when read as a whole.â€Â  Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 665, 594 S.E.2d 462, 472 (2004) (citations omitted). Â Some principles of law, however, are not to be charged to a jury.Â  See, e.g., State v. Grant, 275 S.C. 404, 408, 272 S.E.2d 169, 171 (1980) (holding that although evidence of a defendantâ€™s flight is admissible as circumstantial evidence of guilt, it is improper for the trial judge to instruct the jury on the law of flight, because such an instruction â€œoftentimes has the potential for creating more problems than solutions,â€ as it â€œplaces undue emphasis upon that part of circumstantial evidenceâ€).
Contrary to the majority opinion, we did not hold in Schumpert that this no-corroboration charge was proper.Â  Rather, â€œ[t]aking the charge as a whole, we [found] no reversible error.â€Â  312 S.C. at 509, 435 S.E.2d at 863.[4]Â  We observed that the trial judge, in addition to charging the jury under section 16-3-657, had charged â€œthe jury it could believe any single witness over several, it was the sole judge of the facts, [the trial judge] had no opinion about those facts, and the State had the burden of proving the offense charged beyond a reasonable doubt.â€Â  Id.Â  
I would hold that it is error for a trial court to charge the jury that an alleged victimâ€™s testimony needs no corroboration.Â  Although section 16-3-657 contains current and correct law, it is not a proper subject of a jury charge.Â  Section 16-3-657 prevents courts, either on a dispositive motion at the trial level or on appellate review, from finding a lack of sufficient evidence to support a conviction because the alleged victimâ€™s testimony is uncorroborated.Â  See James Cranston Gray, Jr., Criminal Law-Rape Reform in South Carolina, 30 S.C. L. Rev. 45, 55-60 (1979) (discussing the no-corroboration rule as governing judicial review of the sufficiency of the evidence); cf. Ludy v. State, 784 N.E.2d 459, 463 (Ind. 2003) (holding that the no-corroboration rule is a legal standard for a court reviewing a conviction).Â  Charging this rule does not assist the jury in fulfilling its function of deciding the facts and determing whether the state has proved the charged offense beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  In fact, it â€œhas the potential for creating more problems than solutions,â€[5] for it might cause confusion when read with the general charge on witness credibility.[6] Â 
More important, charging this rule carries a strong possibility of biasing the jury against the defendant.Â  No witnessâ€™s testimony need be corroborated.Â  By specifically charging that the alleged victimâ€™s testimony need not be corroborated, the trial court singles out the alleged victim and â€œappears to express an opinion on her credibility.â€Â  State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 510, 435 S.E.2d 859, 864 (1993) (Finney, J., dissenting); see also S.C. Const. art. V, Â§ 17 (providing that â€œ[j]udges shall not charge juries in respect to matters of fact, but shall declare the lawâ€).Â  I would therefore hold that charging a jury on the contents of section 16-3-657 constitutes error.
Further, I would overrule the holding in Schumpert that the charge as a whole can render this no-corroboration charge harmless.Â  Separately instructing the jury that it may believe one witness against many or many against one does not ameliorate or remove the favorable emphasis on the alleged victimâ€™s testimony.Â  
Furthermore, this case is different from Ludy, supra, in which the Supreme Court of Indiana held that although the trial court had erred in giving the no-corroboration charge, the error was harmless because:Â  â€œ[T]he testimony of the victim was not uncorroborated. ... [A]side from the victimâ€™s testimony there was substantial probative evidence establishing the elements of the charged offenses.â€Â  784 N.E.2d at 463.Â  Here, the only evidence of Petitionerâ€™s committing CSC was the testimony of the alleged victims.Â  The jury had to determine whether it believed the purported victims or Petitioner.Â  
For these reasons, I would hold that the circuit court committed reversible error in charging the jury.Â  I would therefore reverse the decision of the Court of Appeals and remand the case to the circuit court for a new trial.
 Acting Justice Stephen S. Bartlett, concurs.

[1] Â Batson actually prohibits only race-based strikes.Â  J.E.B. v. Alabama, 511 U.S. 127, 114 S.Ct. 1419, 128 L.Ed.2d 89 (1994), is the case prohibiting gender-based strikes.Â  Both types of strikes are popularly referred to as Batson violations.
[2] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-655 (2003).
[3] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-657 (2003).
[4] We cited Lottie v. State, 406 N.E.2d 632 (Ind. 1980), to support this holding.Â  Lottie was recently overruled in Ludy v. State, 784 N.E.2d 459, 462 & n.2 (Ind. 2003).
[5] Grant, 275 S.C. at 408, 272 S.E.2d at 171.
[6] According to the majority opinion, the General Assembly â€œhas decided it is reasonable and appropriateâ€ to instruct the jury that an alleged CSC victimâ€™s testimony need not be corroborated.Â  I can find no indication in section 16-3-657 or elsewhere that the legislature intended this no-corroboration rule to be charged to the jury.Â

title: State v. Downs
description: This death penalty case involves the issue of whether appellant is competent to be executed.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
William E. Downs, Jr., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â L. Casey Manning, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26156
Submitted April 19, 2006 - Filed May 30, 2006Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of the South Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W.Â  McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, of Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE MOORE:Â  We are asked to decide whether appellant, who has been sentenced to die for murder, is mentally competent to waive his right to challenge his conviction and death sentence and be executed.  We conclude appellant is competent.
PROCEDURAL FACTS
Appellant pled guilty to the crimes of murder, kidnapping, and criminal sexual conduct with a minor. Â A hearing was then held to determine whether he was guilty but mentally ill (GBMI).Â  An expert, Dr. Everett Kuglar, testified appellant was mentally ill.Â  However, two other experts, Dr. Jeffrey Musick and Dr. Pamela Crawford, testified appellant was not
mentally ill.Â  After considering the evidence, the court ruled appellant failed to prove he was GBMI.Â  Appellant was subsequently sentenced to death and the sentence was affirmed in State v. Downs, 361 S.C. 141, 604 S.E.2d 377 (2004).
Appellantâ€™s counsel filed a petition for a stay of execution to allow him to file a petition for a writ of certiorari with the United States Supreme Court.Â  The stay petition was granted.Â  Subsequently, appellant notified this Court that he wished to dismiss his appeals and be executed.Â  We remanded this case to the trial court for a competency hearing.Â  Meanwhile, the United States Supreme Court denied counselâ€™s motion, on appellantâ€™s behalf, for leave to proceed in forma pauperis.Â  See Downs v. South Carolina, 544 U.S. 972 (2005).
In February 2005, the first evidentiary hearing was held.Â  Counsel requested more time to allow their psychiatric experts an opportunity to review materials and evaluate appellant.Â  The hearing judge ruled the State would be allowed to offer Dr. Pamela Crawford and Dr. Jeffrey Musick at the hearing, and that the defense would be able to cross-examine those doctors at a later date.
A second evidentiary hearing was held in March 2005.Â  At the beginning of this hearing, counsel moved for a continuance so that Dr. Margaret Melikian, who had met with appellant only once, could treat appellant and see him at least twice more.Â  The court, after hearing evidence, denied the motion.
Following closing statements, the court ruled appellant was competent to be executed under the Singleton v. State[1] standard and that his decision to waive his right to challenge his conviction and death sentence was knowing and voluntary.
ISSUES

  
    
      
        I. 
         Did the lower court abuse its discretion by refusing to grant a continuance of the hearing until appellant could be further evaluated?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        II. 
         Is appellant competent to waive any challenges to his conviction and death sentence?
      
    
  

DISCUSSION
The standard for determining whether an appellant is mentally competent to be executed is set forth in Singleton, supra, and states:

The first prong is the cognitive prong which can be defined as:Â  whether a convicted defendant can understand the nature of the proceedings, what he or she was tried for, the reason for the punishment, or the nature of the punishment.Â  The second prong is the assistance prong which can be defined as:Â  whether the convicted defendant possesses sufficient capacity or ability to rationally communicate with counsel.

Singleton v. State, 313 S.C. at 83, 437 S.E.2d at 58 (emphasis added).
At the February hearing, appellant informed the court he did not want to appeal and wanted to have his competency hearing completed as soon as possible.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  At the hearing, Dr. Pamela Crawford, a court-appointed expert in forensic psychiatry, testified she had evaluated appellant for a GBMI determination on six prior occasions from May 2001 to June 2002.Â  Pursuant to this Courtâ€™s order, she also evaluated appellant for competency, along with Dr. Jeffrey Musick, on February 11, 2005.Â  Dr. Crawford summarized her record review and indicated she learned appellant had attempted suicide while incarcerated.Â  She opined appellant had mild depression that was not sufficient to be diagnosed as major depression.Â  She testified appellant was competent to waive his appeals and be executed under the Singleton standard.Â  Her diagnoses included pedophilia, paraphilia, substance abuse, and antisocial personality disorder.Â  She stated none of these diagnoses impacted on appellantâ€™s ability to understand the proceedings or communicate with his counsel.
Specifically, on the cognitive prong of Singleton, Dr. Crawford stated appellant clearly articulates an understanding of the appeals process, the consequences of waiving his appeals, that he prefers lethal injection, and that he does not have any delusional thoughts about death.Â  On the assistance prong, she opined appellant communicates clearly and that he was willing to work with an attorney who would further his goal of being executed but did not want to work with an attorney who did not want to help further that goal.Â  Dr. Crawford stated there was no evidence appellant had a deteriorating mental disorder and that his status was the same as when he was evaluated in 2001 and 2002.
Dr. Jeffrey Musick, testified he had been involved in the 2002 evaluations of appellant.Â  For purposes of this competency hearing, he stated he met with appellant twice.Â  At the second meeting, he administered several psychological tests.Â  Dr. Musick found appellant had mild depression, but did not have a major disorder.Â  He stated that, during the evaluation, appellant was cooperative, friendly, laughed at the appropriate times, and had rational and coherent speech.Â  He found no evidence of delusions and appellant informed him he thought the legal process had been fair.
Dr. Musick opined appellant met the Singleton requirements for competency.Â  Regarding the cognitive prong, Dr. Musick stated appellant understood the proceedings, what he was tried for, and stated his punishment fit the crime.Â  Appellant was able to relate that it was possible that existence stops when you die and said that would be preferable to living in prison.Â  Appellant stated he hoped for better things after death and that he preferred lethal injection because it was peaceful.Â  Regarding the assistance prong, Dr. Musick testified appellant was able to express himself and understand others.Â  Appellant informed Dr. Musick that he was happy to work with an attorney who had his same goals, i.e. that he be executed.Â  Dr. Musick did not see any potential of appellantâ€™s mental state deteriorating in the future.
On cross-examination, Dr. Musick admitted appellant may have suffered a major depressive episode in the past and that he has been unhappy all his life.Â  Dr. Musick indicated he was aware of appellantâ€™s suicide attempts while incarcerated and of his attempt to commit suicide when he was about ten years old.Â  Dr. Musick stated those facts did not change his opinion that appellant was competent under Singleton.
Dr. Donna Schwartz-Watts, a forensic psychiatrist, testified appellant was very cooperative during her evaluation.Â  She stated appellant had mild depression.Â  As for major depression, she stated he met only four of the five criteria and therefore, was not diagnosed with major depression.Â  She stated that diagnosis could change in the future.
Dr. Schwartz-Watts opined appellant was competent under both prongs of Singleton.Â  She testified appellant met the cognitive prong because he understood the proceedings, his punishment, and that he was able to communicate that he desired lethal injection.Â  She stated he wants to be free but otherwise he wants to be executed instead of being imprisoned.Â  She testified that he does not suffer from delusions and that he hopes for something better in the afterlife.Â  Regarding the assistance prong, Dr. Schwartz-Watts testified appellant met this prong because he could communicate with counsel and that, because he was sometimes irritated with counsel, he chose not to cooperate.Â  She stated her diagnoses were that appellant has depression, not otherwise specified; post-traumatic stress disorder, paraphilia, pedophila, and substance abuse.Â  She opined that none of these diagnoses affect either prong of Singleton.Â  She testified he has a mild form of depression that does not prevent him from doing the things he needs to do and that he could have depression and still be competent under Singleton.Â  She stated that depressive people can function on a day-to-day basis and that it just depends on the severity of the depression.
James Whittle, the attorney who represented appellant for his plea, testified appellant did not wish to contest his guilt and wanted to die.Â  He stated appellant forbade him from offering mitigation evidence but that he was able to seek a guilty but mentally ill finding by telling appellant his case could help others.Â  Whittle felt appellant had significant mental health issues and that he was depressed.Â  Whittle testified he felt appellant was competent to stand trial and had the ability to rationally communicate with him.Â  He stated appellant did not appear to be very different since the time when he was representing appellant.
Dr. Margaret Melikian, a forensic psychiatrist, testified she met with appellant once for a four-hour evaluation on February 28, 2005.Â  She stated appellant was guarded but cooperative during the meeting.Â  She testified regarding her knowledge of appellantâ€™s numerous suicide attempts.Â  Dr. Melikian testified appellant met the cognitive prong of Singleton.Â  However, regarding a diagnosis of appellant, she stated she did not have enough information to rule out a diagnosis of a major depressive episode.Â  Dr. Melikian testified appellant met some of the criteria for being diagnosed with major depression.
Dr. Melikian testified appellantâ€™s wish to waive his appeals process may be a rational decision or a product of his depression.Â  She opined he should be offered treatment for depression and then have his competency reevaluated.Â  For that reason, she stated she could not offer an opinion on his competency.Â  She wanted to see if treatment would cause him to change his mind.Â  She stated appellant told her he would take anti-depressants if the court ordered him to do so.
Dr. Melikian stated appellant does not suffer from any delusions or psychosis.Â  She stated appellant can communicate but she was unsure if he could â€œrationallyâ€ communicate as stated in the assistance prong of the Singleton standard.Â  She agreed that one could meet the criteria of major depression but still be competent under Singleton.Â  However, she had no opinion on appellantâ€™s competency at the time of the hearing.Â  She recommended medication so that a more accurate evaluation could be completed.Â  Significantly, she stated she was unsure if appellant chose not to take drugs voluntarily whether she could form an opinion on the Singleton assistance prong.Â  She stated she would like to see him additional times but she did not know if she would be able to form an opinion.
During closing arguments, counsel for appellant reasserted his request for a continuance so that Dr. Melikian could provide appellant with medication, or at the very least if appellant refused the medication, so that she could meet with appellant at least twice more.Â  The motion for continuance was denied.
Appellant personally addressed the hearing judge.Â  He did not feel Dr. Kuglar (from his previous GBMI evaluation) and Dr. Melikian could state that he was incompetent or depressed given they did not conduct a full mental evaluation. Â Appellant concluded by asking the judge, if he decides competency is proven, to impose an injunction on appellantâ€™s counsel so that he would not file any more motions or other documents in his case because appellant wished to fire him.
In his order, on the cognitive prong of Strickland, the judge found it is evident from the communication appellant had during his recent evaluations that there is a plethora of evidence to support a finding of competency on each factor within that prong.Â  On the assistance prong, the judge found appellant possesses sufficient mental capacity or ability to rationally communicate with counsel.Â  The judge found that, in discussions with himself and each of the evaluators, it was without question that appellant had the mental capacity and ability to express ideas, analyze options, understand the facts and law, and intelligently convey his thoughts and ideas to others.Â  The judge noted the record is void of any evidence that appellant cannot understand any communication with counsel or others due to any mental impairment or that he cannot make himself understood.Â  The judge stated the record indicates appellantâ€™s responses to inquiries have always been rational.Â  
The judge stated he did not share Dr. Melikianâ€™s hesitation on the assistance prong.Â  He stated that, although her desire to treat appellant with medication and see what develops may be well-intentioned, the delay was unnecessary for the court to render its opinion because appellant clearly satisfies the assistance prong.Â  The judge stated, â€œIt is difficult to recall a defendant more attentive and more observant than [appellant.]â€Â  The judge specifically found appellant did not have a present wish to commit suicide or die, but that he has maintained he prefers death to being locked up for the rest of his life.Â  In conclusion, the judge found appellant competent to waive post-conviction proceedings under the Singleton standard.
In appellantâ€™s pro se response, he states he has repeatedly asked counsel not to file any appeals on his behalf.Â  Regarding Dr. Melikianâ€™s belief that appellant should be placed on anti-depressants, appellant states he has been placed on anti-depressants since the time of the hearing.Â  For various reasons, he had to cease taking the medications.Â  While on medication, appellant states he did not at any point think of changing his mind about dropping his appeals.Â  He states he knows he will be in prison for the rest of his life and that he has been sentenced to be executed.Â  He foresees nothing productive coming from being on death row.Â  He concludes, â€œI want to go ahead with my execution A.S.A.P.â€
I. Motion for Continuance
Counsel for appellant argues the hearing judge erred by denying the motion for a continuance and that this case should be remanded with an order allowing Dr. Melikian additional time to possibly medicate appellant and further evaluate him so that she can have a final opinion under the second prong of the Singleton standard.
The hearing judge did not err by refusing counselâ€™s motion for a continuance.Â  The judge appropriately determined that more time was not needed to determine appellantâ€™s competency.Â  Three experts testified appellant was mildly depressed but that this condition did not affect his capacity on either prong of Singleton.Â  Dr. Melikian testified appellant met the cognitive prong, but stated she could not come to a conclusion on the assistance prong.Â  She also was uncertain whether appellant suffered from major depression, rather than mild depression.Â  However, Dr. Melikian admitted that one could meet the criteria of Singleton even if that person suffered from major depression.Â  Most importantly, Dr. Melikian testified that, even if she was allowed to treat appellant with medication and/or see him more times, she was unsure whether she could ever form an opinion on the Singleton assistance prong.Â  The hearing judge gave the proper weight to Dr. Melikianâ€™s testimony when deciding whether a motion for a continuance should be granted.Â  Accordingly, the judge did not abuse his discretion in denying the motion for a continuance.Â  Cf. State v. McMillian, 349 S.C. 17, 561 S.E.2d 602 (2002) (trial judgeâ€™s denial of a motion for continuance will not be disturbed absent a clear abuse of discretion).
II. Competency
A capital defendant may not waive his appellate or PCR rights unless this Court first determines the defendant is competent.Â  See Hughes v. State, 367 S.C. 389, 626 S.E.2d 805 (2006) (Court will issue execution notice if person, who is determined by Court to be mentally competent, knowingly and voluntarily waives appeals and post-conviction relief); State v. Torrence, 317 S.C. 45, 451 S.E.2d 883 (1994) (waiver may not be found unless Court first determines defendant is competent and his decision is knowing and voluntary).
In making a determination on the competency of a convicted defendant to waive his appellate or PCR rights, we are not bound by the circuit courtâ€™s findings or rulings,
although we recognize the circuit court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, is in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  See Hughes v. State, supra.Â  It is this Court which must finally determine whether a particular appellant is mentally competent to make a knowing and voluntary waiver of his appellate or PCR rights.Â 
Id.Â  In deciding the issue of an appellantâ€™s competency, we carefully and thoroughly review the appellantâ€™s history of mental competency; the existence and present status of mental illness or disease suffered by the appellant, if any, as shown in the record of previous proceedings and in the competency hearing; the testimony and opinions of mental health experts who have examined the appellant; the findings of the circuit court which conducted a competency hearing; the arguments of counsel; and the appellantâ€™s demeanor and personal responses to any questions at oral argument regarding the waiver
of appellate and PCR rights.Â  Id.
As noted previously, the standard for determining whether an appellant or PCR applicant is
mentally competent to waive the right to a direct appeal or PCR includes a cognitive prong and an assistance prong under Singleton.Â  The failure of either prong is sufficient to warrant a stay of execution and a denial of the convicted defendantâ€™s motion to waive his right to appeal or pursue PCR.Â  Hughes v. State, supra.
We find appellant is competent and comprehends his circumstances, such that the waiver of his appeals and PCR is knowing and voluntary.Â  Although appellant has been diagnosed as having mild depression, this diagnosis does not affect appellantâ€™s capacity on either the cognitive or assistance prong of Singleton.
At the hearing, the two State experts:Â  Drs. Crawford and Musick, and one of the defense experts, Dr. Schwartz-Watts, all testified that appellant suffered from mild depression and not major depression.Â  The doctors all testified appellant was competent to waive his appeals under Singleton.Â  On the cognitive prong of Strickland, the doctors, including Dr. Melikian, testified appellant met this prong.Â  They all testified appellant had an understanding of the appeals process, the consequences of waiving his appeals, and an understanding of his death sentence and the finality of that sentence.
Drs. Crawford, Musick, and Schwartz-Watts also testified appellant met the assistance prong of Singleton.Â  Dr. Crawford testified appellant can communicate clearly and was able to discuss his desires and that he was willing to work with an attorney who would further his goal of being executed but that he did not wish to work with an attorney who would hinder that goal.Â  Dr. Musick and Dr. Schwartz-Watts gave similar testimony.
Appellantâ€™s former counsel, James Whittle, testified that, while he felt appellant had significant mental health issues and was depressed, appellant was competent to stand trial and had the ability to rationally communicate with him.Â  Whittle stated appellantâ€™s condition did not seem to have changed since the time he represented appellant.Â  Therefore, at this point in the hearing, the only evidence presented was that appellant was competent.
The defense expert, Dr. Melikian, however, felt she needed more time to make a proper diagnosis of appellantâ€™s depression and whether he was competent to waive his appeals.Â  Dr. Melikianâ€™s testimony, however, does not prevent a finding of competency in light of the other expert testimony.Â  The other experts clearly found appellant competent and that he had met each prong of Singleton.Â  Further, the fact Dr. Melikian was unsure she could ever reach an opinion on the assistance prong is significant.Â  Finally, on the point of Dr. Melikianâ€™s wish that appellant be medicated, appellant, himself, wrote to this Court and stated he had been placed on anti-depressants after the hearing.Â  While on medication, appellant stated he did not think of changing his mind about dropping his appeals.Â  He stated, as he has consistently stated throughout the proceedings, that he wishes to proceed with his execution as soon as possible.
Accordingly, we find appellant is competent to waive his appeals and be executed.Â  Further, his decision to waive is knowing and voluntary.Â  Therefore, the hearing judgeâ€™s findings are
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]  313 S.C. 75, 437 S.E.2d 53 (1993).

title: Palmetto Princess v. Town of Edisto Beach
description: This case involves the issue of whether the circuit court erred by finding the Town of Edisto's ordinance preventing a gambling day cruise business violates the South Carolina Constitution.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Palmetto Princess, LLC, Respondent,
v.
Town of Edisto Beach, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Colleton County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26157
Heard January 4, 2006 - Filed May 30, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Marvin C. Jones and R. Clenten Campbell, both of Bogoslow, Jones, Stephens & Duffie, of Walterboro, for appellant.
Heath Preston Taylor, of Moore, Taylor & Thomas, P.A., of West Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE MOORE:Â  This is an appeal from a circuit court order granting respondentâ€™s (Palmetto Princessâ€™s) motion for summary judgment.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On February 23, 2003, Palmetto Princess applied for a business license from appellant, the Town of Edisto Beach (Edisto).Â  Palmetto Princess intended to operate one or more gaming vessels on cruises originating within the waters and municipal boundaries of Edisto.Â  The plan was for the vessels to travel beyond the three mile territorial waters of the State of South Carolina, at which point games such as black jack, roulette, and craps would be hosted for Palmetto Princessâ€™s customers.Â  These gambling cruises are known as â€œcruises to nowhere.â€Â  The cruises would conclude, and debarkations take place, within Edistoâ€™s municipal boundaries.
Edisto denied Palmetto Princessâ€™s application.Â  Edisto based its denial on the Town of Edisto Beach Code Â§ 58-138.Â  Section 58-138 specifically prohibits the possession of a gambling device on a vessel within the waters of the municipal boundaries of Edisto operated for the purposes of conducting a day cruise.
Palmetto Princess commenced a declaratory judgment action seeking to set aside Town of Edisto Beach Ordinance Â§ 58-138 based partly on the grounds that:Â  (1) Edisto did not have the power to enact the ordinance because the Johnson Act, 15 U.S.C.A. Â§ 1171, et seq., restricts the prohibition of gaming activity to states or possessions of the United States; that is, that the Johnson Act preempts the local legislation embodied in the ordinance; and (2) Â§ 58-138 violates article VIII, Â§ 14, of the South Carolina Constitution.Â  Both parties filed motions for summary judgment.
The circuit court held Edistoâ€™s ordinance is not preempted by the Johnson Act.[1]Â  However, the court granted Palmetto Princessâ€™s motion for summary judgment based on the alternative ground that Edistoâ€™s ordinance violates the South Carolina Constitution.Â  The court found that because Â§ 58-138 prohibits an activity otherwise legal within the state, Â§ 58-138 violates the state constitution.Â  Citing Diamonds v. Greenville County, 325 S.C. 154, 480 S.E.2d 718 (1997), the court stated that the draftersâ€™ intent for article VIII, Â§ 14, was to prevent local governmentâ€™s making an act a crime that was not a crime under state law.Â  Accordingly, the court granted summary judgment to Palmetto Princess on its declaratory judgment action.
ISSUE

Did the circuit court err by finding Town of Edisto Beach Ordinance Â§ 58-138 violates article VIII, Â§14, of the South Carolina Constitution?

DISCUSSION
Edisto argues the circuit court erred by finding its ordinance, Â§ 58-138, violates article VIII, Â§14, of the South Carolina Constitution.
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 5-7-30 (2004) provides:Â  â€œEach municipality of the State . . . may enact . . . ordinances, not inconsistent with the Constitution and general law of this State, . . . for preserving health, peace, order, and good government in it . . . .â€Â  (Emphasis added).
South Carolina Const. art. VIII, Â§ 14 provides:Â  â€œIn enacting provisions required or authorized by this article, general law provisions applicable to the following matters shall not be set aside:Â  . . . (5) criminal laws and the penalties and sanctions for the transgression thereof . . . .â€
As stated previously, Ordinance Â§ 58-138 specifically prohibits the possession of a gambling device on a vessel within the waters of the municipal boundaries of Edisto operated for the purposes of conducting a day cruise.Â  This ordinance was enacted in 1999.Â  However, subsequently, we held that â€œcruises to nowhereâ€ are not unlawful.Â  Stardancer Casino, Inc. v. Stewart, 347 S.C. 377, 556 S.E.2d 357 (2001).Â  Therefore, at the time Edistoâ€™s ordinance was enacted and Palmetto Princess had requested a business license to operate a gambling day cruise, a gambling day cruise was a legal activity allowed by the State. [2] 
Because a gambling day cruise was a legal activity allowed by the State, Edistoâ€™s ordinance is unconstitutional because it makes a legal activity unlawful. Â See Connor v. Town of Hilton Head Island, 314 S.C. 251, 442 S.E.2d 608 (1994) (where ordinance proscribed conduct which was not unlawful at the time the ordinance was enacted under state criminal laws governing the same subject, town exceeded its power in enacting ordinance); and Diamonds v. Greenville County, supra (same).Â  Where the General Assembly has occupied the field in a particular area, i.e. gambling, by describing what is and what is not proscribed, local governments are not free to alter the standards established by the General Assembly. Â Cf. Quality Towing, Inc. v. City of Myrtle Beach, 340 S.C. 29, 530 S.E.2d 369 (2000) (ordinance upheld where there was no relevant state law governing conduct in question).
CONCLUSION
Because Edisto exceeded its power in enacting the ordinance in question, the circuit court properly granted summary judgment to Palmetto Princess.Â  See Cunningham ex rel. Grice v. Helping Hands, Inc., 352 S.C. 485, 575 S.E.2d 549 (2003) (summary judgment appropriate only if there is no genuine issue of material fact and moving party is entitled to judgment as matter of law).Â  Therefore, the decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED
TOAL, C.J., PLEICONES, J. and Acting Justice Ralph King Anderson, Jr., concur.Â  BURNETT, J., dissenting in a separate opinion.
BURNETT, J.:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In my opinion, Edisto did not exceed its power in enacting Ordinance Â§ 58-138 because the Ordinance did not set aside any statewide criminal laws.Â  
South Carolina Constitution Article VIII, Â§ 14, provides:Â  â€œIn enacting provisions required or authorized by this article, general law provisions applicable to the following matters shall not be set aside: . . . (5) criminal laws and the penalties and sanctions for the transgression thereof . . . .â€ 
When construing the Constitution, the Court applies rules similar to those relating to the construction of statutes.Â  Davis v. County of Greenville, 313 S.C. 459, 463, 443 S.E.2d 383, 385 (1994).Â  In construing a statute, its words must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.Â  First Baptist Church of Mauldin v. City of Mauldin, 308 S.C. 226, 229, 417 S.E.2d 592, 593 (1992).
As I explained in Diamonds v. Greenville County, 325 S.C. 154, 161, 480 S.E.2d 718, 721 (1997) (Burnett, J., dissenting): 


 Article VIII, Â§ 14 does not require statewide uniformity of
general law provisions regarding â€œcriminal laws and the penalties and sanctions for the transgression thereof.â€
Instead, the preamble to Article VIII, Â§ 14, provides â€œgeneral law provisions applicable to the following matters
shall not be set aside.â€ (emphasis added). The plain meaning of this provision requires local enactments â€œset
asideâ€ some existing provision of the general law before a constitutional violation occurs.


In my opinion, Article VIII, Â§ 14 of the South Carolina Constitution does not prohibit local governments from criminalizing conduct which is not unlawful under state law.Â  Until the Gambling Cruise Prohibition Act was enacted, there was no legislative action that made a gambling day cruise a legal activity.Â  Further in Stardancer Casino, Inc. v. Stewart, 347 S.C. 377, 387-91, 556 S.E.2d 357, 362-64 (2001) (Burnett, J., dissenting), I would have held â€œboats located within South Carolina and its territorial waters are subject to the same laws concerning gambling as any other premises in this state.â€Â  I therefore disagree with the majorityâ€™s conclusion that gambling day cruises are lawful.Â  Ordinance Â§ 58-138 could not and did not set aside any statewide criminal laws.
The majority also relies on Connor v. Town of Hilton Head Island, 314 S.C. 251, 442 S.E.2d 608 (1994) for the proposition that conduct which is not unlawful under state laws cannot be made unlawful by local enactment.Â  In my opinion the Connor Court erred because the Court effectively held all conduct is lawful unless made unlawful by enactment of the General Assembly.Â  Article VIII, Â§ 14 does not yield to such an interpretation.Â  I would overrule Connor to the extent it holds that local governments may not criminalize conduct which is not unlawful under statewide criminal law.
    
Edistoâ€™s Ordinance Â§ 58-138 does not set aside any criminal laws enacted by the state because the ordinance is not inconsistent with any state law.Â  Therefore, I would hold Edisto did not exceed its power in enacting Ordinance Â§ 58-138.Â  I conclude the circuit court improperly granted summary judgment to Palmetto Princess.


[1]The circuit courtâ€™s ruling regarding preemption is not before the Court.Â  However, for edification, the Johnson Act generally prohibits the use or possession of any gambling device on a United States flag vessel.Â  One exception is that the possession or transport of a gambling device within state territorial waters is not a violation of the prohibition if the device remains on board the vessel and is used only outside those territorial waters.Â  15 U.S.C. Â§ 1175(b)(1). 
[2]Subsequent to the circuit courtâ€™s order issued in this case, the General Assemblyâ€™s Gambling Cruise Prohibition Act was signed into law by the governor with an effective date of June 1, 2005.Â  Section 3-11-200(A) of this Act specifically allows the type of ordinance enacted by Edisto.
