title: Hearst-Argyle Television v. Williams
description: This is a reversal of the trial courtâ€™s decision closing the courtroom during a pre-trial suppression hearing in a capital murder case.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

Ex parte:

  
    
      
Hearst-Argyle Television, Inc., d/b/a WYFF TV-4, and The Greenville News, a division of the Gannett Pacific Corporation,
Intervenors-Appellants,
      
    
  

In Re:

  
    
      
The State,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Charles Christopher Williams,
Both of Whom are Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Greenville County
Â J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26159
Heard May 3, 2006 - Filed May 30, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
Carl F. Muller and Wallace K. Lightsey, both of Wyche Burgess Freeman & Parham, of Greenville, and Rivers S. Stilwell, of Nelson Mullins Riley & Scarborough, of Greenville, for Appellants.
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, Deputy Solicitor Betty C. Strom, and Assistant Solicitor Andrew Burke Moorman, all of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  


 CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Hearst-Argyle Television and The Greenville News (collectively â€œAppellantsâ€) appeal the trial courtâ€™s decision closing the courtroom during a pre-trial suppression hearing in a capital murder case.Â  We reverse.
Factual/Procedural Background
This case arises out of Charles Christopher Williamsâ€™ (Defendantâ€™s) trial for the murder of his former girlfriend (Victim).Â  In July of 2003, Defendant assaulted Victim as she left her job at a Greenville grocery store.Â  Police arrested Defendant and charged him with assault and battery with intent to kill (ABIK).Â  While out of jail and awaiting trial on the ABIK, Defendant entered Victimâ€™s workplace with a shotgun and held her hostage for several hours.Â  The incident ended when police stormed the grocery store and found Victim dead.Â  Police arrested Defendant at the crime scene, and an autopsy revealed that Victim had been shot four times with a shotgun.
Prior to trial, issues arose regarding statements Defendant made to police.Â  Specifically, Defendant gave police a lengthy confession immediately after his arrest and a forensic psychiatrist interviewed Defendant for several hours immediately thereafter.Â  Defendantâ€™s testimony to the psychiatrist yielded incriminating information and also led police to discover a journal Defendant kept which contained additional incriminating evidence.Â  One week prior to selecting the jury for Defendantâ€™s trial, Defendant moved to suppress the journal and the statements he made to the psychiatrist.
Immediately, this case received a great deal of media attention.Â  Several television stations broadcast live from the grocery store during the hostage standoff, and Appellant Greenville News published at least thirty-eight news and opinion articles either exclusively devoted to this case or addressing the case in the broader context of â€œthe domestic violence problem in South Carolina.â€
The trial court held most of the pre-trial proceedings in Anderson in hopes that the media would not attend.Â  Prior to the hearing on Defendantâ€™s motion to suppress, this strategy was successful.Â  In fact, until the suppression hearing, the media did not attend any of the pre-trial proceedings.Â  Appellants sent reporters to the suppression hearing however, and after these reporters identified themselves to the trial court, the court announced its intention to close the courtroom.[1]Â  
Appellants requested a hearing to allow their attorneys to present arguments opposing closing the courtroom.Â  While Appellants phoned their attorneys, the court asked the parties if limiting the hearing to legal arguments regarding suppression might allow Appellants to remain present.Â  Defendant voiced strong opposition to the presence of the media, expressing concern about not being able to prevent witnesses from discussing substantive facts in their answers.
After Appellantsâ€™ attorneys arrived, the court conducted a hearing on closing the courtroom.Â  Relying on precedent of this Court and the United States Supreme Court, the trial court held that a courtroom may be closed only upon specific findings showing â€œa substantial probability of prejudice from publicity that closure would prevent and [that] thereâ€™s no reasonable alternatives.â€Â  Relying on the fact that this case involved the â€œhot buttonâ€ issue of domestic violence, an issue which had played prominently in the mediaâ€™s coverage of the case, and because this case also involved sensitive racial issues, the court closed the suppression hearing.Â  
Though not relevant to the merits of this appeal, the trial court denied Defendantâ€™s motion to suppress. The trial proceeded, and a jury convicted Defendant and sentenced him to death.Â  This appeal followed,[2] and Appellants raise the following issues for review:

  
    
      
        I.  
         Did the trial court close the courtroom without sufficient justification?
      
      
        
          
      
      
        II.      
         Did the trial court violate Appellantsâ€™ procedural due process rights in closing the courtroom?
      
    
  

Law/Analysis 
Although both the suppression hearing and the criminal trial in this case have concluded, we review the case despite its mootness because, as courts have generally held in these cases, closing the courtroom is a wrong â€œcapable of repetition yet evading review.â€Â  See In re S.C. Press Assâ€™n, 946 F.2d 1037, 1039 (4th Cir. 1991); and Ex parte Columbia Newspapers, Inc., 286 S.C. 116, 118, 333 S.E.2d 337, 338 (1985) (citing Gannett v. DePasquale, 443 U.S. 368 (1983) and Steinle v. Lollis, 279 S.C. 375, 307 S.E.2d 230 (1983)). 
I. Justification for Closure
Appellants argue the trial court closed the suppression hearing without sufficient justification.Â  We agree.
The rights of the public and the press to attend criminal trials are guaranteed by the South Carolina Constitution and the United States Constitution.Â  Because the majority of â€œclosed courtroomâ€ cases focus largely on the federal constitutional analysis and jurisprudence, we begin there.
United Stated Supreme Court has interpreted the guarantees of free speech and freedom of the press found in the First Amendment to the United States Constitution to include a constitutional guarantee of open and public courts.Â  Richmond Newpapers, Inc. v. Virginia, 448 U.S. 555, 580 (1980).Â  Because the court views the rights of the public and press as constitutionally guaranteed, the First Amendment analysis applies a strong presumption favoring open criminal proceedings.Â  In re Charlotte Observer, 882 F.2d 850, 852 (4th Cir. 1989); In re Knight Publishing Co., 743 F.2d 231, 234 (4th Cir. 1984). Â This presumption may only be overcome by an overriding interest based on specific findings that closure is necessary to preserve â€œhigher values,â€ and the closure must be narrowly tailored to serve that interest.Â  In re Charlotte Observer, 882 F.2d at 852-53 (citing Press-Enterprise Co. v. Superior Court of California, 478 U.S. 1, 13-14 (1986) (Press Enterprise II)); In re Knight Publishing Co., 743 F.2d at 234 (citing Press-Enterprise Co. v. Superior Court, 464 U.S. 501, 510 (1984) (Press Enterprise I)).
When the alleged â€œhigher valueâ€ justifying closure is protecting the defendantâ€™s Sixth Amendment right to trial by an impartial jury, the courtroom may be closed only if specific findings are made that (1) there is a substantial probability that the defendantâ€™s right to a fair trial will be prejudiced by publicity, (2) there is a substantial probability that closure would prevent that prejudice, and (3) reasonable alternatives to closure could not adequately protect the defendantâ€™s rights.Â  In re S.C. Press Assâ€™n, 946 F.2d at 1041; In re Charlotte Observer, 882 F.2d at 853.Â  Additionally, the trial court must list specific findings justifying closure so an appellate court may review the decision and determine its correctness.Â  In re Knight Publishing Co., 743 F.2d at 234. Â Courts have generally interpreted this requirement as establishing a de novo standard of review.Â  In re Charlotte Observer, 882 F.2d at 853 (citing In re Washington Post, 807 F.2d 383, 381 (4th Cir. 1986)).
Although South Carolina, like the federal courts, has a rich jurisprudential history in the area of courtroom closure, the origins of the state and federal guarantees of open courtrooms are quite different.Â  Â Our Constitution parallels the United States Constitution in numerous ways.Â  For example, article I, Â§ 2 of the South Carolina Constitution is strikingly similar to the First Amendment to the United States Constitution.Â  Also, article I, Â§ 14 of the South Carolina Constitution provides the equivalent of the Sixth Amendmentâ€™s guarantee of a speedy and public trial to a criminal defendant.Â  Arguably, the difficulty the federal courts experienced in the early stages of closed courtroom jurisprudence involved finding a constitutional basis for the guarantee of open courtrooms.[3]Â  As we have explained, the federal courts eventually interpreted the First Amendment in such a manner as to provide this guarantee, and the federal law in this area has largely become well-settled.Â  
In South Carolina, however, our Constitution contains a particular provision that has no parallel at the federal level.Â  Specifically, our Constitution provides â€œ[a]ll courts shall be public, and every person shall have speedy remedy therein for wrongs sustained.â€Â  S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 9.[4]Â  While federal case law was still in considerable flux, our jurisprudence recognized article I, Â§ 9â€™s independent constitutional guarantee of open courts and held â€œ[e]xclusion of the press and public from judicial proceedings is a drastic measure calling for a careful weighing of interests affected.â€Â  Steinle v. Lollis, 279 S.C. 375, 376-77, 307 S.E.2d 230, 231 (1983).Â  As both federal and state law evolved, we clarified that a judgeâ€™s decision to close any proceeding must be supported by specific findings explaining the balancing of the interests at stake and the need for closure.Â  Ex parte Island Packet, 308 S.C. 198, 201, 417 S.E.2d 575, 577 (1992) (explicitly adopting Press Enterprise IIâ€™s test); Ex parte Columbia Newspapers, 286 S.C. at 118-19, 333 S.E.2d at 338 (relying on Steinle and article I, Â§ 9 of the South Carolina Constitution, as well as Gannett).
Although the state and federal constitutional origins of these rights are substantially different, we now hold that the test for reviewing the propriety of closing a courtroom under the South Carolina Constitution is identical to the First Amendment analysis of the issue.Â  This holding is grounded in the fact that this Courtâ€™s earliest precedent closely mirrors the current First Amendment analysis of this issue, and in the fact that this Court has continually relied on both state and federal precedent in analyzing these cases.[5]
In the instant case, the trial court relied on concerns about racial issues and the â€œhot buttonâ€ issue of domestic violence in closing the pre-trial suppression hearing.Â  Though these concerns were no doubt genuine, closing the courtroom could not possibly have alleviated either of them.Â  As the record demonstrates, closing the courtroom had no effect on Appellantsâ€™ abilities to publish or disseminate news about Defendantâ€™s case.Â  Though the trial court had the ability to prevent the press from attending the suppression hearing, the court did not have the ability to prevent the press from speaking on the subject matter.Â  Indeed, preventing the press from attending the suppression hearing had no impact on the pressâ€™ ability to further publicize Defendantâ€™s race, crime, or any issue related to his case.Â  Thus, assuming there was a substantial probability that pre-trial publicity would prejudice Defendant, closing the courtroom could not have prevented that prejudice.
Additionally, it is helpful to discuss another of the trial courtâ€™s concerns involving the mediaâ€™s presence at the suppression hearing, though it was not specifically articulated in the courtâ€™s justifications for its decision.Â  In this case, the trial court was concerned that details of Defendantâ€™s confession to the psychiatrist might be revealed in the hearing and subsequently published by the media.Â  Similar, however, to the justifications offered above, this concern would also fail to support closure.Â  We believe the trial courtâ€™s original suggestion to limit the hearing to legal arguments addressing suppression would be sufficient to alleviate this fear.Â  Additionally, we take this opportunity to reiterate that jury voir dire is the preferred and generally accepted tool that protects a defendant from the prejudicial effects of pre-trial publicity.Â  In re Charlotte Observer, 882 F.2d at 855.
Because closing the courtroom had no effect on preventing additional publicity regarding Defendantâ€™s case, the case as it related to the issue of domestic violence in South Carolina, or any racial issues involved in the trial, we reverse the trial courtâ€™s decision closing the pre-trial suppression hearing. [6] 


II. Procedural Due Process
Appellants allege the trial court closed the courtroom in violation of their procedural due process rights.Â  Specifically, Appellants allege the trial court closed the hearing sua sponte and without giving Appellants adequate notice and a meaningful opportunity to be heard.Â  We disagree.
First, we note that the trial court, in this case, did not close the courtroom on its own motion.Â  Although the court stated its intention to close the hearing on its own motion if Defendant did not make a motion first, the record clearly indicates that Defendant made an oral motion to close the courtroom.Â  Therefore, the argument that the court closed the courtroom sua sponte is without support in the record.
If, however, the trial court had closed the courtroom sua sponte, the distinction would not be significant.Â  In In re S.C. Press Assâ€™n, the fourth circuit upheld the trial courtâ€™s decision closing voir dire after the trial court sua sponte issued a notice that it would hold a closure hearing.Â  946 F.2d at 1039.Â  Because the court raised the issue on its own motion, no formal notice was docketed prior to the hearing.Â  Id.Â  The fourth circuit upheld the trial courtâ€™s decision, and in doing so, the court held that this process gave the press and public adequate notice and opportunity to voice opposition to the courtâ€™s decision.Â  Id.
Appellantsâ€™ argument, â€œthat a court cannot, in some circumstances, raise matters on its own motion,â€ overstates the case and ignores the critical balance at work in closed courtroom cases.Â  Although the public and the press have constitutionally guaranteed rights in the courtroom, those rights are not absolute and will sometimes compete with and obstruct a criminal defendantâ€™s constitutionally secured right to receive a fair trial.Â  In criminal cases, the trial court has a duty to protect a defendantâ€™s constitutional right to a fair trial.Â  Sheppard v. Maxwell, 384 U.S. 333, 362-63 (1966).Â  We decline to take such a view of these cases as to, with one hand, charge the trial court with the duty of protecting both the defendantâ€™s and the publicâ€™s constitutional rights, and with the other hand, hamstring the court by requiring it to refrain from considering these issues until asked to do so.Â  If closing the courtroom is the only available option to prevent the substantial probability that publicity would prejudice the defendantâ€™s right to a fair trial, the trial court may raise the issue on its own motion, conduct the required hearing, and issue a ruling.
Regarding notice and an opportunity to be heard, in this case, the trial court identified Appellantsâ€™ presence in the courtroom, announced his intention to close the courtroom, and asked Appellants if they had any comment.Â  Appellants requested a hearing during which they could argue against closing the courtroom, and the trial court held a hearing on closure where both Appellants were represented by legal counsel.
In closed courtroom cases, individual notice is not required.Â  In re Knight Publishing Co., 743 F.2d at 235.Â  Generally, notifying the persons present in the courtroom â€œreasonably in advance of deciding the issueâ€ is appropriate.Â  Id.[7]Â  Here, the trial court alerted Appellantsâ€™ representatives of its intentions, and the court allowed Appellantsâ€™ attorneys a meaningful opportunity to be heard on the issue.Â  Appellants provided the trial court with the relevant authority on the issue, and each presented skillful arguments.Â  In our view, it would indeed take a skewed view of the record to conclude that the trial courtâ€™s decision making process in this case violated Appellantsâ€™ procedural due process rights.
Conclusion
Although we are satisfied that the trial court in this case paid careful consideration to Appellantsâ€™ due process rights and applied the proper legal standard, we hold that the reasons offered in support of closing the courtroom were insufficient to justify infringing upon the state and federal constitutional guarantees of open courts. Â Â We believe the trial courtâ€™s justifications are accurately re-characterized as concerns regarding additional pre-trial publicity and its possible effect on being able to draw an impartial jury.Â  Because closing the suppression hearing had no effect on preventing additional publicity of the trial, we reverse.
MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] The court initially stated that if Defendant did not move to close the proceeding, the court would do so sua sponte.Â  Later, Defendant made an oral motion to close the proceeding.
[2] Although this appeal does not involve the merits of Defendantâ€™s conviction or sentence, the appeal came directly to this Court because Defendantâ€™s trial resulted in a death sentence.Â  See Rule 203(d)(1)(A), SCACR (stating that an appeal in a death penalty case is heard in this Court).Â  Defendantâ€™s direct appeal to this Court is currently pending.
[3] Compare Gannett v. DePasquale, 443 U.S. 368, 391-92 (1978) (holding that the members of the public have no constitutional rights under the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments to attend criminal trials, and assuming arguendo that the First Amendment guarantees the public a right to attend pre-trial criminal proceedings, the trial court heard arguments in objection to the closure and adequately â€œbalanced the â€˜constitutional rights of the press and publicâ€™ against the â€˜defendantsâ€™ right to a fair trial.â€™â€), with Richmond Newpapers, Inc. v. Virginia, 448 U.S. 555, 580 (1980) (stating â€œthat the right to attend criminal trials is implicit in the guarantees of the First Amendment; without the freedom to attend such trials . . . important aspects of freedom of speech and â€˜of the press could be eviscerated.â€™â€).Â  
[4] In State v. Lagerquist, 254 S.C. 501, 506, 176 S.E.2d 141, 143 (1970), we declined to interpret the latter portion of this provision as guaranteeing a right to a speedy appeal in a criminal case.Â  Additionally, we clarified that the latter portion applies only to civil proceedings.Â  Id.Â  (stating that construing the provision to apply to criminal trials would render article I, Â§ 14â€™s guarantees superfluous).Â  These interpretations are not relevant to this case, however, because they have no bearing on the unqualified language at the beginning of the section.
[5] Arguably, our analysis begins by determining whether the particular type of proceeding has historically been open and whether public scrutiny plays a significant role in the functioning of the proceeding.Â  Ex parte Island Packet, 308 S.C. at 201, 417 S.E.2d at 577 (citing Press Enterprise II). This inquiry is unnecessary in this case because this Court has recognized the publicâ€™s right of access to pre-trial suppression hearings.Â  See In re Greenville News, 332 S.C. 394, 396, 505 S.E.2d 340, 341 (1998) (citing Waller v. Georgia, 467 U.S. 39, 47 (1984)).Â  Again, this proposition is strengthened by the South Carolina Constitutionâ€™s unqualified language guaranteeing open courtrooms.Â  
[6] Although we reverse the trial courtâ€™s ultimate decision, we are satisfied that the trial court applied the proper legal standard in considering this issue.Â  Though the court initially referred to the case of Gannett v. DePasquale and to Rule 605(f)(iii), SCACR (governing media coverage of court proceedings), as the relevant authority in this area, the courtâ€™s articulation of the test, that there be â€œa substantial probability of prejudice from publicity that closure would prevent and [that] thereâ€™s no reasonable alternatives,â€ is a proper restatement of the constitutional analysis mandated by the Island Packet and Press Enterprise II decisions.
[7] Appellants rely on In re Knight Publishing Co., and argue that the trial court had already made his decision before he held the hearing.Â  The record does not support this argument; particularly in light of the trial courtâ€™s statements before and during the hearing.Â

description: This appeal raises issues relating to whether a mechanicâ€™s lien was timely perfected and the denial of prejudgment interest to the prevailing party.  The Court affirmed the trial courtâ€™s decision regarding timeliness of perfection of the lien, and reversed the trial courtâ€™s decision denying prejudgment interest to the prevailing party.
text:
BENCH MEMORANDUM


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Butler Contracting, Inc., Respondent/Appellant,
v.
Court Street, LLC; Morris Construction Co.; and Central Carolina Bank,
Defendants,
Of whom Court Street, LLC, and Morris Construction Co. areÂ Appellants/Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Greenville County
Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Opinion No. 26160
Heard April 19, 2006 - Filed May 30, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Thomas E. Dudley, III, and John T. Crawford, Jr., both of Kenison & Dudley, LLC, of Greenville, for Appellants/Respondents.
Craig H. Allen, of Greenville, for Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


 CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This appeal raises issues relating to whether a mechanicâ€™s lien was timely perfected and the denial of prejudgment interest to the prevailing party.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
Factual/Procedural Background
Butler Contracting, Inc. (Subcontractor) signed a contract with Morris Construction Co. (Contractor) to provide labor and materials for interior walls and ceilings in a commercial renovation project.Â  Court Street, LLC (Owner) hired the companies to transform and expand a former church site in Greenville into condominiums.Â  The original contract amount between Subcontractor and Contractor was $493,156.[1]Â  Including additional work and change orders, Subcontractor asserted it was owed a total of $713,364, of which Contractor paid $536,363, leaving a balance due of $177,001.Â  
Henry Holseberg, a principal owner of both Owner and Contractor who apparently controlled both companies, did not dispute the original contract amount, the various amounts for additional work and changes asserted by Subcontractor, or the amount still owed to Subcontractor.Â Â  Owner, however, filed a counterclaim seeking an offset for $94,878 in damages allegedly caused by delays attributable to Subcontractor and work which Subcontractor failed to timely or properly perform.[2]
During construction, Owner or Contractor apparently began having financial difficulties and fell behind in payments to various companies working on the project.Â  Contractor did not prepare contemporaneous records of tasks Subcontractor allegedly failed to perform or provide detailed back-charges to Subcontractor as the project progressed.Â  Instead, Contractor declined to pay Subcontractorâ€™s invoices in full.Â  After Subcontractor filed a notice of mechanicâ€™s lien and a lawsuit seeking to enforce the lien, Contractor reviewed past records such as time and material sheets in an attempt to document the proper amount of back-charges allegedly owed by Subcontractor.Â  Contractorâ€™s staff made these calculations during or after Holsebergâ€™s deposition; some two years after the project was completed.Â  
Holseberg testified the work Subcontractor failed to do included work in the church basement, repairing areas damaged by other subcontractors, completing changes requested by owners who had purchased units, and completing â€œpunch listsâ€ of minor problems in finished units.Â  Contractor eventually hired a drywall finisher fired by Subcontractor to help complete the necessary work.Â  There apparently was some degree of miscommunication and disagreement between the parties regarding changes and repairs, with Subcontractor insisting it properly performed the work and objecting to potential back-charges due to confusion about which company had performed repairs.Â  
Subcontractor provided labor and materials at the project on a regular basis from mid-1999 until December 2000, although it apparently was not constantly at the jobsite due to delays caused by asbestos removal and the work of other subcontractors.Â  Danny Hodge testified Subcontractor was supposed to perform additional work in the church basement after December 2000, and was ready, willing, and able to do so, but Contractor never asked Subcontractor to complete the work.
In early 2001, Subcontractor, at the request of Contractorâ€™s supervisor, delivered one box of ceiling tiles to replace tiles at the project which had been damaged by water leaks.Â  Hodge testified the ceiling tiles were surplus materials from the project stored at Subcontractorâ€™s warehouse.Â  Subcontractor routinely included the cost of replacing some damaged ceiling tiles in its estimates, and often provided replacement tiles even though it was not explicitly required to do so by a particular contract.Â  A project foreman for Contractor signed a form accepting delivery of the tiles.Â  Holseberg testified the tiles were not needed, although he was uncertain whether they were used. 
Subcontractor filed a notice and certificate of its mechanicâ€™s lien in circuit court approximately one month after delivering the ceiling tiles.Â  About two months later, Subcontractor filed a lawsuit in circuit court against Owner and Contractor, asserting causes of action based in contract, the mechanicâ€™s lien statute, and quantum meruit.Â  Subcontractor sought the balance due of $177,001, attorneyâ€™s fees, prejudgment interest, and foreclosure and sale of the real property to satisfy its lien.
The case was referred with finality to a master-in-equity.Â  After a bench trial, the trial court found the mechanicâ€™s lien had been timely served and recorded as required by statute.Â  The trial court awarded $152,001 to Subcontractor, which represented a reduction of $25,000 from the original demand stemming from delays attributable to Subcontractor.Â  The trial court did not offset any damages claimed by Contractor for work it allegedly performed that was Subcontractorâ€™s responsibility.Â  Subcontractor requested payment of attorneyâ€™s fees of $43,529 as the prevailing party, and the trial court separately awarded $35,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The trial court denied Subcontractorâ€™s request for prejudgment interest.
Owner and Contractor appealed and Subcontractor cross-appealed.Â  We certified this case from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and the parties present the following issues for review:

  
    
      
        I.Â 
         Did the trial court err in ruling Subcontractor timely served and recorded its mechanicâ€™s lien?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        II. 
         Did the trial court err in ruling Subcontractor was not entitled to prejudgment interest on the balance due?
      
    
  

Standard of Review
A proceeding for the enforcement of a statutory lien, such as a mechanicâ€™s lien, is legal in nature.Â  Willard v. Finch, 123 S.C. 56, 116 S.E. 96 (1923); Stoudenmire Heating & Air Conditioning Co. v. Craig Bldg. Partnership, 308 S.C. 298, 301, 417 S.E.2d 634, 636 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  In an action at law, when a case is tried without a jury, the trial courtâ€™s findings of fact will be upheld on appeal when they are reasonably supported by the evidence.Â  Stated another way, the trial courtâ€™s findings of fact will not be disturbed on appeal unless wholly unsupported by the evidence or unless it clearly appears the findings were influenced or controlled by an error of law.Â  The trial courtâ€™s findings in such a case are equivalent to a juryâ€™s findings in a law action.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976); Willard, 123 S.C. at 58, 116 S.E. at 96; Stoudenmire, 308 S.C. at 301, 417 S.E.2d at 636.
Law/Analysis
I.Â  Perfection of Mechanicâ€™s Lien
Owner argues the trial court erred in ruling that Subcontractor timely served and recorded a mechanicâ€™s lien within the statutory ninety-day deadline.Â  Owner asserts that Subcontractorâ€™s â€œunilateral, unsolicited deliveryâ€ of one box of ceiling tiles to the jobsite did not revive Subcontractorâ€™s expired right to file a mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  The delivery of â€œsurplus materialsâ€ was not required by the contract, and the materials were â€œmerely provided as a gratuity or an act of friendly accommodation.â€Â  In fact, the delivery was nothing more than â€œa contrived effort to revive lien rights.â€Â  We disagree.
â€œA person to whom a debt is due for labor performed or furnished or for materials furnished and actually used in the erection, alteration, or repair of a building or structure upon real estate,â€ by virtue of an agreement with or with the consent of the owner or his agent, shall have a mechanicâ€™s lien upon the real property to secure payment of the debt.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(a) (Supp. 2005).Â  The right to a lien arises inchoate; i.e., when the labor is performed or material is furnished, the right exists but the lien has not been perfected.Â  Preferred Sav. and Loan Assn., Inc. v. Royal Garden Resort, Inc., 301 S.C. 1, 3, 389 S.E.2d 853, 854 (1990); Wood v. Hardy, 235 S.C. 131, 138, 110 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1959); Williamson v. Hotel Melrose, 110 S.C. 1, 30, 96 S.E. 407, 409 (1918).Â  When the person claiming the lien was employed by someone other than the owner, such as a contractor, he must notify the owner of the furnishing of labor or material in order for the lien to attach to the property.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-40 (1991); Lowndes Hill Realty Co. v. Greenville Concrete Co., 229 S.C. 619, 629, 93 S.E.2d 855, 860 (1956); Shelley Constr. Co. v. Sea Garden Homes, Inc., 287 S.C. 24, 26-27, 336 S.E.2d 488, 490-91 (Ct. App. 1985).[3]Â  
In order to perfect and enforce a mechanicâ€™s lien, the person asserting the lien (1) must serve upon the owner or person in possession and file with the register of deeds or clerk of court a notice or certificate of lien containing the lien amount, a description of the real property, and other required information â€œwithin ninety days after he ceases to labor on or furnish labor or materials for such building or structureâ€; (2) must commence a lawsuit seeking to enforce the lien within six months after ceasing to provide labor or materials for such real property; and (3) must file a notice of the pending action (lis pendens) within six months after ceasing to provide labor or materials for such real property. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 29-5-90 and 29-5-120 (1991 & Supp. 2005); Preferred Sav. & Loan Assn., 301 S.C. at 3-4, 389 S.E.2d atÂ  854; Franke Associates by Simmons v. Russell, 295 S.C. 327, 329, 368 S.E.2d 462, 463 (1988); Multiplex Bldg. Corp. v. Lyles, 268 S.C. 577, 235 S.E.2d 133 (1977); Crystal Pools, Inc. v. Old Claussenâ€™s Bakery Partners, 303 S.C. 68, 399 S.E.2d 5 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  If these steps are taken, the person claiming the lien may foreclose against the property to satisfy the debt.Â  On the other hand, if he fails to take any one of these steps, the lien against the property is dissolved pursuant to Sections 29-5-90 and 25-9-120.Â  The failure to perfect a mechanicâ€™s lien does not preclude an action on the debt.Â  Shelley Constr. Co., 287 S.C. at 27, 336 S.E.2d at 490.Â  
The time limits run from the same event: Â the certificate of lien must be filed within ninety days, and the foreclosure suit (and accompanying notice of pending action) must be commenced within six months after the person asserting the lien ceases to furnish labor or materials.Â 
The effect of these provisions is that the six-month limitations period for enforcing the lien necessarily commences no later than the date the certificate of lien is
filed. If suit is not commenced within six months after the date the certificate of lien is filed, title examiners may assume that the mechanicâ€™s lien is dissolved.[4] Â Â Preferred Sav. & Loan Assn., 301 S.C. at 4-5, 389 S.E.2d at 854-55.Â  A mechanicâ€™s lien is purely statutory.Â  Therefore, the requirements of the statute must be strictly followed.Â  Lyles, 268 S.C. at 578, 235 S.E.2d at 134.
In Wood, a residential contractor abandoned the construction of a house midway through the job.Â  The materials provider had not been paid by the contractor.Â  The materials provider agreed to furnish the rest of the materials, and the provider and homeowner agreed to hire others to complete the house.Â  The homeowner moved into the house upon completion.Â  Approximately one month later, the materials provider, acting upon a complaint by the homeowner, sent a plumber to properly complete the kitchen drain line by installing two pieces of pipe costing about $4.Â  The materials provider subsequently served and filed a notice of mechanicâ€™s lien within ninety days of effecting the minor plumbing repair, but not within ninety days of the provision of any other material or labor.Â  Wood, 235 S.C. at 133-36, 110 S.E.2d at 157-59.
The homeowner argued the minor plumbing repair was so â€œtrivial or inconsequentialâ€ that it was insufficient to extend the time for serving a mechanicâ€™s lien beyond the date the bulk of materials and labor had been provided.Â  This Court disagreed, noting, as other courts had in similar cases, that the statute does not specify any particular amount of materials or labor which must be furnished.Â  Wood, 235 S.C. 136-40, 110 S.E.2d at 159-61.
â€œ[W]here a claimant, after a contract is substantially completed, does additional work or furnishes additional material which is necessary for the proper performance of his contract, and which is done in good faith at the request of the owner or for the purpose of fully completing the contract, and not merely as a gratuity or act of friendly accommodation, the period for filing the lien will run from the doing of such work or the furnishing of such materials, irrespective of the value thereof.â€Â  Wood, 235 S.C. at 140, 110 S.E.2d 157 at 161.Â  The deadline to serve and record a mechanicâ€™s lien begins running from the date the last material was furnished or work performed, regardless of whether such material or work is insignificant and regardless of whether the final work is delayed, provided the reason for the delay is not to improperly extend the period for perfecting the lien.Â  Id.; accord Crystal Pools, 303 S.C. at 68, 399 S.E.2d at 5 (warranty work performed by carpeting contractor five months after initial installation of carpeting, which was necessary to complete performance under the contract, constituted furnishing of labor or materials and extended time for perfecting mechanicâ€™s lien).
The position adopted in Wood, as reflected in foreign precedent cited in that 1959 opinion, has not changed substantially in more recent cases from other courts.Â  â€œ[W]hen an unreasonable period of time has elapsed since substantial completion of the work, the performance of trivial services or the furnishing of trivial materials generally will not extend the time for filing the certificate past the date of substantial completion. . . .Â  If, however, subsequent to the date of substantial completion, trivial services or materials are provided at the request of the owner, rather than at the initiative of the contractor for the purpose of saving a lien, the furnishing of such work or material will extend the commencement of the period for filing a certificate of mechanicâ€™s lien.â€Â  F.B. Mattson Co. v. Tarte, 719 A.2d 1158, 1161 (Conn. 1998) (holding that, although roofing project had been substantially completed more than a month earlier, deadline to file mechanicâ€™s lien began to run upon removal of scaffolding and roofing brackets from property at request of owner); accord Franklin Bldg. Supply Co. v. Sumpter, 87 P.3d 955, 959-61 (Idaho 2004) (deadline to file mechanicâ€™s lien began to run when builder purchased a sheet of cedar and locking door handle for house, not when certificate of occupancy was issued several weeks earlier; although dollar value of items was minimal, they were actually used in constructing and repairing the home, were reasonably necessary to complete construction and punch list according to terms of contract, were not merely trivial or insubstantial, and purchases were not intended to extend time for filing lien); Interstate Elec. Servs. Corp. v. Cummings Props., LLC, 825 N.E.2d 1059, 1063-64 (Mass. App. 2005) (mere delay in completing contract and performance of trifling items of work have never been held under Massachusetts statute fatal to maintenance of a mechanicâ€™s lien when work was done in good faith and was necessary to a complete performance of the contract); Security Ben. Life Ins. Corp. v. Fleming Companies, 908 P.2d 1315, 1321-22 (Kan. App. 1995) (for purposes of mechanicâ€™s lien filing deadline, store checkout system installer last performed work on date it set up direct store delivery system and trained employees on its use; although other work was completed earlier, work performed on that date was necessary to comply with terms of contract); 53 Am.Jur.2d Mechanicsâ€™ Liens Â§ 211 (1996).
In the present case, Contractor asked Subcontractor to provide a single box of ceiling tiles to replace water-damaged tiles.Â  As shown by a delivery form signed by Contractorâ€™s supervisor, Subcontractor provided the tiles in early 2001.Â  The trial court correctly ruled that Subcontractor, in this instance, furnished additional materials which were necessary for the proper performance of the contact, and did so in good faith at the request of Contractor or for the purpose of fully completing the contract.Â  Subcontractor did not provide the materials merely as a gratuity or an act of friendly accommodation; nor did Subcontractor provide the materials merely to improperly extend the period for perfecting its lien.
Subcontractor routinely provided such materials on its projects to properly complete the job and foster a good reputation.Â  Although it was not explicitly required by contract to leave surplus tiles on site or replace tiles damaged by others during the construction process, the parties implicitly considered the provision of such materials necessary to comply with the contract and fulfill the duty of good faith and fair dealing which is an implied term of every contract.Â  E.g. Tharpe v. G.E. Moore Co., 254 S.C. 196, 201, 174 S.E.2d 397, 399 (1970) (â€œThere exists in every contract an implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.â€).
The trial courtâ€™s ruling that the deadline for Subcontractor to file a mechanicâ€™s lien began to run upon delivery of the box of ceiling tiles to the jobsite at the request of Contractor is reasonably supported by the evidence.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision that Subcontractor timely perfected its mechanicâ€™s lien pursuant to Sections 29-5-90 and 29-5-120.
II.Â  Prejudgment Interest
Subcontractor contends the trial court erred in denying its request for prejudgment interest because the amount owed was certain or capable of being reduced to certainty upon demand for payment.Â  We agree.
The law has long allowed prejudgment interest on obligations to pay money from the time when, either by agreement of the parties or operation of law, the payment is demandable, if the sum is certain or capable of being reduced to certainty.Â  Smith-Hunter Constr. Co. v. Hopson, 365 S.C. 125, 128, 616 S.E.2d 419, 421 (2005); Babb v. Rothrock, 310 S.C. 350, 353, 426 S.E.2d 789, 791 (1993); Ancrum v. Slone, 29 S.C.L. (2 Speers) 594 (1844).Â  Stated another way, prejudgment interest is allowed on a claim of liquidated damages; i.e., the sum is certain or capable of being reduced to certainty based on a mathematical calculation previously agreed to by the parties.Â  Prejudgment interest is not allowed on an unliquidated claim in the absence of an agreement or statute.Â  Babb, 310 S.C. at 350, 426 S.E.2d at 791; Builders Transport, Inc. v. S.C. Prop. & Cas. Ins. Guar. Assn., 307 S.C. 398, 406, 415 S.E.2d 419, 424 (Ct. App. 1992); Wayne Smith Constr. Co. v. Wolman, Duberstein, and Thompson, 294 S.C. 140, 146-47, 363 S.E.2d 115, 119 (Ct. App. 1987).
The fact that the amount due is disputed by the opposing party does not render the claim unliquidated for the purposes of an award of prejudgment interest.Â  The proper test for determining whether prejudgment interest may be awarded is whether the measure of recovery, not necessarily the amount of damages, is fixed by conditions existing at the time the claim arose.Â  Smith-Hunter Constr. Co., 365 S.C. at 128, 616 S.E.2d at 421; Babb, 310 S.C. at 353, 426 S.E.2d at 791; Wayne Smith Constr. Co., 294 S.C. at 146-47, 363 S.E.2d at 119.Â  The right of a party to prejudgment interest is not affected by rights of discount or offset claimed by the opposing party.Â  It is the character of the claim and not the defense to it that determines whether prejudgment interest is allowable.Â  Lee v. Thermal Engineering Corp., 352 S.C. 81, 88-89, 572 S.E.2d 298, 302 (Ct. App. 2002); Southern Welding Works, Inc. v. K & S Constr. Co., 286 S.C. 158, 164, 332 S.E.2d 102, 106 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  
A judgment debtor is required to pay interest on his debt as compensation for his continued retention and use of the creditorâ€™s money beyond the date payment was due.Â  Sears v. Fowler, 293 S.C. 43, 45-46, 358 S.E.2d 574, 575 (1987).Â  In South Carolina, prejudgment interest is set by statute at annual rate of 8Â¾ percent, although parties are free to agree, within legal limits, on a higher rate of interest.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 34-31-20(A) (Supp. 2005); Turner Coleman, Inc. v. Ohio Constr. & Engr., Inc., 272 S.C. 289, 292, 251 S.E.2d 738, 740 (1979).
In the present case, the trial court denied Subcontractorâ€™s claim for prejudgment interest because there was a â€œgood faith dispute by [Owner and Contractor] as to the amount due.â€Â  This ruling conflicts with established law and it is not reasonably supported by the evidence.
The parties do not dispute the amount of the original contract.Â  Including additional work and change orders, Subcontractor asserted it was owed a total of $713,364, of which Contractor paid $536,363, leaving a balance due of $177,001.Â  Contractor did not dispute the various amounts for additional work and changes asserted by Subcontractor, or the amount still owed to Subcontractor.Â  Contractor, however, filed a counterclaim seeking an offset for $94,878 in damages allegedly caused by delays attributable to Subcontractor and work which Subcontractor failed to timely or properly perform.
We hold the trial court erred in denying the award of prejudgment interest because Subcontractor asserted a claim for liquidated damages.Â  The amount Contractor owed Subcontractor was a certain sum or capable of being reduced to a certainty based on contractual provisions regarding the amount of the original contract, the amount of change orders approved by Contractor, and payments made by Contractor.Â  In this case, the trial court should have awarded prejudgment interest to Subcontractor after determining the amount Contractor owed Subcontractor.Â  Furthermore, Contractorâ€™s assertion of a counterclaim seeking an offset does not prevent an award of prejudgment interest because it is the character of the claim and not the defense to it that determines whether prejudgment interest is allowable.
We reverse the trial courtâ€™s order refusing to award prejudgment interest to Subcontractor and remand this case for calculation of prejudgment interest on the sum of $152,001 from the date Subcontractor filed its notice and certificate of mechanicâ€™s lien in circuit court.
Conclusion
We affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision that Subcontractor timely perfected its mechanicâ€™s lien and the verdict awarding damages to Subcontractor.Â  We reverse the trial courtâ€™s order refusing to award prejudgment interest to Subcontractor and remand this case for the calculation of such interest.Â  
We affirm the rulings of the trial court on the remaining issues raised by Owner and Contractor pursuant to Rule 220(c), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  Issues II, III, and IV:Â  Willard v. Finch, 123 S.C. 56, 116 S.E. 96 (1923); Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976); Stoudenmire Heating & Air Conditioning Co. v. Craig Bldg. Partnership, 308 S.C. 298, 301, 417 S.E.2d 634, 636 (Ct. App. 1992).
MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice R. Knox McMahon, concur.

[1]Â  We have rounded off dollar amounts.
[2]Â  Owner purchased a surety bond pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-110 (Supp. 2005) to release the lien against the real property.
[3]Â  Section 29-5-40 does not contain a time limit for providing written notice to the owner when the person asserting the lien is employed by someone other than the owner.Â  Wood, 235 S.C. at 138, 110 S.E.2d at 160; Lowndes Hill Realty Co., 229 S.C. at 629, 93 S.E.2d at 860; see also Stovall Bldg. Supplies, Inc. v. Mottet, 305 S.C. 28, 32, 406 S.E.2d 176, 178 (Ct. App. 1990) (reversing foreclosure on mechanicâ€™s lien because material supplier, which had contract with subcontractor, failed to give required notice of lien to homeowner before homeowner paid general building contractor in full). 
[4]Â  As we have explained: 

If the certificate of lien is filed on the date that labor ceases, suit must be brought within six months thereafter. Â For each additional day between the date of cessation of labor and the date of filing, the time between filing and commencement of suit is reduced by one day. Â Thus, if the certificate were filed on the 90th day after cessation of labor, suit must be commenced three months after the filing.Â  

Preferred Sav. & Loan Assn., 301 S.C. at 4 n.1, 389 S.E.2d at 855 n.1.

The Supreme Court of South Carolina
In re: Amendments to Rule   501, Canon 4, of the South   Carolina Appellate Court Rules

ORDER

Pursuant to Article V, § 4, of the South Carolina   Constitution, Rule 501, Canon 4(F), South Carolina Appellate Court Rules, is   hereby amended to read as follows:

  F.  Service as   Arbitrator or Mediator.  A judge shall not act as an arbitrator or mediator   or otherwise perform judicial functions in a private capacity unless expressly   authorized by law.*  However, a retired judge may act as an arbitrator or   mediator and remain available for assignment as a judge by the Chief Justice of   the Supreme Court, provided the judge is disqualified: (1) from mediation and   arbitration in matters in which the judge served as judge; and (2) as a judge   from matters in which the judge participated as mediator or arbitrator. 
	 

The   amendment is effective immediately.  
 
IT IS SO ORDERED.

Respondent pled guilty to one count of accommodation distribution of marijuana in violation of 21 U.S.C. Â§ 841(b)(1)(D) and Â§ 841(b)(4) and one count of possession of methylenedioxymethamphetamine hydrochloride, also known as MDMA or â€œecstasy,â€ in violation of 21 U.S.C. Â§ 844(a).Â
